Such a chill game to play solo or with friends, and there is almost always something you could be doing. You could work on your farm, go into the mines, the friendship mechanic, just so much. Also, there is clear progression unlike animal crossing, with the years. Lets you know what the next steps to take are, not just throwing you in completely blind.

By far one of my favourite games. I previously played it for hundreds of hours on the Xbox Gamepass and I plan to get it on my Switch too. It's the perfect mix of open gameplay with objectives to help you focus if you want to complete them. It's clever, has great characters, and a storyline I love. ConcernedApe will always be the Goat! (ConcernedGoat?)

[b] Review after 100% Completion [/b] [i] *Again* [/i]

[i] I have 100% completed this around 2017, around Patch 1.2. Then 1.6 was released, and I noticed that it was gone in my Completionist Showcase. [/i] 

I‚Äôm kind of shocked that I did not review this perfect game before, as I definitely enjoyed my time playing and returning to this game. I have been thinking about how great Harvest Moon's NYE Festival at the Summit was, and the fact that CA has added something akin to it, yet in a much harder way, is [i] Perfection. [/i] Winter 21, Year 7 is the day I achieved it, with no Joja services used!

Bring on the 1.7 Update, as I still have not gained an Auto-Petter, Living Hat, Tea Set, or even an Iridium Krobus. Also, please add a dog frisbee mini-game or some secret bachelor/bachelorette (Sandy and definitely Robin üòà).

This game really makes you *feeel* like a farmer. (Remember that Spider-Man PS4 reference? Eh? Eh?) In all seriousness though, this is one of my most favorite games of all time. Plenty to do and work towards without being overly "grindy" It's a great game for if you just feel like relaxing. It's definitely a good go-to winter game for me when I have nothing else I can really be doing.

This game has an absolutely wonderful mix of modern/cartoonish elements while still having a retro kind of nostalgic feeling. The calming music allows you to completely drift into peace, and you can play at any pace you wish. The Developer (ConcernedApe) regularly updates the game so you have lots of fun additions if you take a break or even if you don't. I've played this game on multiple consoles, and I'm so excited to see an active and amazing community that surrounds it. One of my favorites!

And if vanilla is too boring or fast paced for you, there are mods that lets you slow it down or make it more fun. Some of them being cosmestic mods, two of my favorite mods is "SH's Animals and Myths pack" and "Elle's Seasonal Buildings"

I first got to play this for free on Apple Arcade, which was a bunch of fun, but I became so addicted that I decided to get the regular game. It's still just as addicting, and the UI/UX experience is a lot better. It's a great game. It takes a lot of time, but the achievements actually have impact and there is a SURPRISING amount of realism when it comes to the human situations and interactions. It's a game that lets you feel very good about being a good samaritan, which is actually... really nice. You definitely get a great sense of accomplishment and peace as you help out the small town, and there's enough experimentation in how you can approach your farm that there's a lot of replayability.

stardew valley is full of personality and heart, has so much to do and explore, and is so vast in the ways that you can play the game that it truly is a unique experience for everyone who picks the game up. want to optimize and minmax as much as possible? go right ahead! want to relax, grow some crops, and meet all of the wonderful characters of pelican town? the world is your oyster! want to mod the game so the horse is pam and the cat is vulpix and everyone is a straw? i'd have some questions, but sure, you can do that too! after nearly 600 hours logged, it is my favourite game ever and i highly recommend this game to anyone who happens to be scrolling the reviews and debating whether to get it or not; it's genuinely one of the most delightful and addicting experiences i've ever had the pleasure of having. those 15 dollars will be well worth it.

Fantastic game with TONS of depth to it. You can never get bored in stardew as theres so many things you can try, fishing, farming, mining, combat, relationships, There really is no end to stardew and I've got 300 hours on my PS4. Glad to support ConcernedApe and his team on steam too :)

A very calm and relaxing game that a majority of people can enjoy. I think that even IF you're not a huge game fan, you'd be able to still enjoy the game due to it mainly focusing on farm first, combat second. You can play forever without (really) fighting any enemy. I'm not BIG on time restrictive things, but this makes the game feel.. more real. Wait a week for crops, then profit! Or just go to the caves (when unlocked) to fight some bats or slimes to get some coins that way! You ENJOY the game for THE GAME and what it has. And I enjoyed the game for what it's worth, but with such a good price with LOADS of content is a blessing.

At first I had hard time liking this game, but it started to grow on me. Now I'm over +250 hours deep, and I just have to achieve the perfection. There is no other way. 

Couple of things still annoy me:
- You can't go to Robin's or Wizard's shop without all the ingredients in your bag to build/upgrade something. Even if you had all the things in your farm's inventory. It would make things so much easier.
- The inventory's size, like what the hell? Why can't I send stuff straight to my farm, if my inventory fills up.

Still, you should play this game, if you love farm simulations, deep stories and character developments,

I have put a frankly shameful amount of hours into this game, I 100%ed it years ago and have hardly touched it since, and I'm a bit shocked that I never left a review. It's such a great time, such a quaint little community. There's a lot to see and explore, I remember how excited I was when the island got added and I got to explore this fresh new part of a game that I had come to know so well. It truly felt like an adventure, something I think is rare for a game to achieve. Thank you, Concerned ape, from the bottom of my heart for the effort you put into this beautiful world. I look forward to Haunted Chocolatier and whatever comes after.

This is, objectively speaking, a good game.

The community is thriving (Shoutout to Wand of Sparking for getting me to try it to begin with), the developer is one hell of a guy, listening and interacting with the very same community and constantly giving us more updates while ignoring the very same community begging him to stop doing that and work on his next game. It's an amazing time with friends, I'm sure.

But, that said, it is not for me. I still recommend it for anyone who enjoys to lose themselves into hours of a calm, methodic RPG/Farming experience.

An all-time classic. A solo dev who adored the Harvest Moon series and yearned for a worthwhile sequel took it upon himself to deliver that dream and, in doing so, created the best entry the genre has ever seen.

You can't say enough great things about this title or its creator, who continues to pour his heart into Stardew Valley through years of free updates.
It's a cozy game, which gives you a feeling of progress and also goes much deeper than it appears on the surface.

I was a huge Harvest Moon fan as a child, and Stardew Valley satisfied that nostalgic craving and much more! There is so much to do in the game that you never get bored. I love playing this game when I'm stressed and need to relax. The 1.6 update added so much content and it's exciting to still keep finding new little things from the update.

One of my very favourite games! Cosy and relaxing, I love that the goal is about building a peaceful, joyful life with a thriving community of friends rather than making money or something like that.  I love making my farm beautiful and all the little sweet moments like patting the animals every day just to make them happy. I also like that the townsfolk have their own rich lives and relationships, with some very moving storylines that can break your heart at times but always move towards hope. There's so much to explore beyond the farm, highly recommend this game.

I‚Äôve only put a little time into it, but I just cannot get into this game at all. Every session leaves me totally checked out, and the whole thing just feels wildly overhyped to me. The craft behind it is great and the polish is obvious, but it is not clicking with me. I usually stick to sci-fi titles, so that probably explains a lot. I personally wouldn‚Äôt push anyone toward it, though people who love cozy farming games will probably enjoy it more than I did.

Downloaded Stardew Valley just to vibe‚Ä¶ now look at me. Every night I tell myself, ‚ÄúOne more day then I‚Äôm going to bed.‚Äù Then the game hits me with a stray cutscene, my crops are almost ready, Shane looks depressed again, the mines are calling my name, and suddenly I‚Äôm like, "After all why not? Why shouldn't I play one more day??‚Äù

Stardew Valley:  (5/5 stars)
I started playing Stardew Valley ‚Äújust to see what the hype was about.‚Äù That was 1 weeks ago. I haven‚Äôt seen sunlight since.
What was supposed to be a relaxing little farming sim has completely hijacked my life. I told myself I‚Äôd play for an hour before bed. Next thing I know, it‚Äôs 4 a.m., I‚Äôm in the caves again. My crops are perfectly watered, my animals are brushed and loved, my spouse brings me coffee every morning, and somehow this pixelated valley has become more real to me than my actual responsibilities.
The addiction is unreal, I cry real tears when my favorite chicken gets eaten by a wild animal because I was too busy fishing at 2 a.m. 
There is no endgame. There is only perfection percentage slowly creeping toward 100% while my real-life social skills atrophy. My friends text me and I reply ‚Äúsorry can‚Äôt talk, it‚Äôs the night market.‚Äù I‚Äôve spent actual money on multiple copies just so I can co-op with myself on different devices. Send help. Or more cauliflower seeds.
10/10 would abandon all adult responsibilities again. Grandfather‚Äôs ghost knew exactly what he was doing leaving me that cursed farm. Best worst decision of my life. If you value your free time, run. If you want to know true happiness (and mild sleep deprivation), welcome to Pelican Town. I‚Äôll save you a spot at the saloon. First round‚Äôs on me‚Ä¶ right after I finish this one last mine run.

I was dead set on not playing this game for years, simply because I hate the graphic style. I am not a "retro pixels" kind of girl. However, I let myself be convinced when me and my boyfriend were doing long distance, so that we could build something together. Partly because we play vastly different games in general, but also because I do love a good city builder and farming sim. It was not love at first sight in any way. I had tried a few days earlier, but I do not do well with sandbox games, and get annoyed with having to figure stuff out..
As you can see though, I now have almost 450h in the game, so it won me over in the end. I did need the co-op mode to get into it, but it is a very lovely game to play together with a partner or friend. I am currently knee deep in trying to get a perfectionist run, though I absolutely did not make it easier for myself by choosing the mountain farm. I do love the challange, but at this point it gets very grindy, and I can only play 2-4 days in one go before getting tired of hunting Pepper Rexes in the dessert mines, or trying to find the right ores to ship. I have also completely given up on the prarie king ;) 

This is a long AF comment on a game for no other reason than to say that you should try it. But perhaps with a friend who has some experience in the game, and also, keep a tab on the Wiki open.

Never before has a game so completely engrossed, stressed, and rewarded my mind quite like Stardew Valley, though it's method of doing so is likely to vary in reflection of it's player. Stardew provides a simple basis initially - farming crops, selling them for cash, and then choosing to spend it however you see fit. But then the question is, how far do you go? Which crop is most profitable per season, and how many can you reasonably maintain over their growing period? Do you perhaps find a different activity more interesting, farming not your taste? Well then, that works too - dedicate yourself to catching high-quality fish found in only select waters, or optimise exploration of the forests for mass foraging of berries and fruits. Got more of a combative nature? Take to the mines, fighting through monsters and exhaustion levels to plumb the depths for valuable treasures. Bit of a homebody, looking to relax? Build relationships with the people around you - learn their interests, their dynamic schedules, complete requests and favours. Expand your house, indulge in interior design, live in luxury. Purchase animals, process their goods over the long-term, and then sell them for ludicrous prices. Maybe get married, have a kid or two - or don't, and instead pledge your love to the profit margins instead. Honestly, this game has something for literally everyone - and so, I must highly recommend it.

This is one of the most fun games I have played since getting my first computer in the early 80's. It has everything: combat, crafting, gathering, building, fishing, and exploration. Don't let the pixel graphics fool you, there is a lot of depth to this game.

Stardew Valley is a relaxing farming game built around steady, satisfying routines. You inherit an old farm and rebuild it however you choose. Its core loop‚Äîplanting, harvesting, mining, and fishing‚Äîfeels simple but engaging. The pixel art and gentle soundtrack create a warm, peaceful atmosphere. The townspeople bring personality and depth to the world, making relationships meaningful. Exploring new areas rewards curiosity and adds variety. Progress is slow, but it feels earned and personal. The game encourages balance between work, exploration, and connection. Its themes of community and renewal give it emotional weight. Overall, it stands out as a cozy experience that still offers depth and purpose.

Clearing the backlog: For nine years I've repeatedly tried to get into Stardew, but invariably bounced off because it's the epitome of twee and saccharine indie cosiness. I love the premise on paper, but ignoring its sticky sweet vibes isn't really viable in practice. However, it's clearly a well-made game, and the target audience adores it. It's just not to my taste, and I suppose it's time to finally move on, but thumbs up nonetheless for clearly being a great ultra-cosy farming/social simulator if that's what you're after.

This is one of my favourite indie games of all time. It's an amazing game, the mechanics are super fun + you are free to play in in so many different ways. If you're looking for a chill game this is perfect, just start a farm and go with the flow. If you want a challenge, you might want to speedrun perfection without tools or something, idk. Be creative and do what you want! There are also a million mods with which you can play around - there's even a BG3 mod!!! 

I hate that you have to play the whole day (around 14 min) for your progress to save, but this makes it even more addicting. Each time your character goes to sleep, you say to yourself "just 14 more minutes". The only people I don't recommend this to are the ones with addictive personalities. It's really hard for me to be consistent with anything for more than a few days, but this game got me hooked instantly and it still hasn't let go after a few months.

The game is great, I particularly like how generous the game is with the timing of which you choose to do things.
Generally speaking, you can "finish" the game at any point in time, year 1, year 2, year 7, doesn't really matter!
The game doesn't rush you and lets you take your time at your own leisurely pace, which i think really does help the game have a nice relaxing charm that you can always come back to and reliably make you more relaxed!
The npcs are all quite charming and have pretty interesting dialogue and stories (Not counting post marriage shane)
So far, the main issue I find myself facing in this game is that the later content tends to feel quite annoying when factoring the lack of an armor system or some kind of defense against attacks until WAYYY later into the game, and how much more dialogue could've been given to the residents of stardew valley since it gets repetitive if you've played for a while. But, thankfully these are not issues that take away from the game's main selling point which is it's farming and community! Both are quite lovely and I'm glad to say I haven't personally had a bad experience with the community!! Will continue to play this for quite a while! It's just so fun! I'll add more to this later if I feel I missed anything but I think that about covers it

If Stardew Valley had been released when I was playing Harvest Moon 64 on my old CRT, I probably would have melted out of happiness. The way it almost magically reproduces the same feeling of walking into a tiny town where everyone has their weird things, secrets, and work hours that you wouldn't really believe... but still it feels like home is something unique to it. 

In my childhood, while playing Harvest Moon 64, I would get so excited with the moment of my first row of turnips that I could swear I was doing a sacred ritual. The music was calm, the villagers had just enough personality to intrigue my little brain, and the whole world was incredibly warm. Stardew Valley actually brings back that very emotional memory and it says, "Hey, do you remember that? Let's do it again but bigger, deeper, and somehow more personal." 

This game is more than just a farm simulator, the emotional aspect is its main feature. Every day is a small adventure: you could be mining, fishing, or running madly across town because you forgot it was someone's birthday and you want to give them a flower like a frenzied postman. The villagers are very real characters, in fact, they remind me of the old days when every heart event was like finding a new page of someone's diary. 

What about the nostalgia? It is there... very strong. Such moments like standing on your farm porch when it is raining or watching the fireflies lighting up the night are exactly the same as those long childhood nights spent trying to marry Karen or figure out what the heck Kappa really was. 

But besides being the spiritual successor of Harvest Moon 64, Stardew Valley is its mature, emotionally savvy, and endlessly attractive evolution. The game is not stuck in the past but it is still there to pay homage to that era. It is that warm feeling of belonging which you get to experience once again through this game... yet you can also have everything on sprinklers, become friends with a wizard, fight cave monsters, or turn your farm into a vineyard because you are worthy of nice things. 

To put it shortly if you were a fan of Harvest Moon 64 during your childhood, then Stardew Valley isn't just a familiar notion, it is like returning home after a long time and seeing that the porch light is still on.

Even having been out so long Stardew Valley holds up. There's a good reason new farm sims are always advertised as Stardew but with ____. If you're wondering if it's still worth it to pick this game up when it's older now and so many new games have come out I'd day overwhelmingly yes. For myself as a long-time player picking it up again feels a bit like home and the modding community is HUGE if base game ever starts feeling a little stale. Stardew is overwhelming a labor of love and it shows in the best way.

The game is quite open ended even as farm sims go, especially in the very beginning. Some people find the lack of direction overwhelming, but I love the freedom of focusing on what I want to do when I feel like doing it, so keep in mind what kind of gamer you are. As an older game it lacks some of the really clean QOL features some newer cozy games have but never in a way I've found to be imperative.

I've sold my soul to the cultivation of my farm and my ever-growing empire of wine production. Cute NPC interactions and good story aspects. Finished the game, will play again... and again. I've already convinced several people to download and play this game.

If you like planning and organizing you will enjoy maxing out stats, developing farm layouts, and running for completion. If you are just looking for a cozy game, water your plants, go fishing, enjoy the town events, and Romance some NPCs. There are so many options and quests in this game that you can either finish in <2 years in game (with extensive planning and maybe even a spreadsheet or two) or you can still be developing your farm and making friends in year 5+.

Mod-Friendly game for graphics or functional mods (items, clothes, buildings). Co-op is also very enjoyable (runs well).

This is the ultimate relaxation game. When the world is too much, I escape to Stardew Valley. Given the age of the game, I'll keep my summary short (as you can easily search to find anything you need). There is no time limit, the objectives are not imposing, and customization is peak. If you're not satisfied, there are hundreds of mods available to fully customize your experience. It may not be for everyone; its admittedly a different kind of gameplay loop. But if you can get into it, the game is surprisingly rewarding. A slightly hidden gem that is absolutely worth your time.

You come into Stardew Valley, hoping to throw away your past life of working mindlessly for Joja to create more shareholder value.

Day 1: You plant your parsnip seeds
Day 15: You take in your second harvest to purchase a new pickaxe
Day 34: You get into the mines to gather materials for your first sprinkler
Day 59: Your farm automated; You being populating your barns
Day 72: You use kegs, preserve jars and speed-gro to maximise your profits during a season
Day 120: Why care about seasons when you can just spam ancient fruits on ginger island?

You want to leave your old life, but you were never able to leave behind your desires, to squeeze out that extra dime out of your millions of earnings.

Makes me really wonder am I just the same as Joja, only in farmer wear instead of suits. Is the game, or society in general, engineered to push everyone to optimise their own gains?

This all came from a game about farming.

Stardew valley is a relaxing game with no clear goals or directions
The game is very clearly an analogy for real life with all it‚Äôs systems mimicking a farm life
So if nothing interests you in it just for the sake of doing that something then the game won‚Äôt interest you
The one thing that stood out to me the most are the really short days and the even shorter shops opening hours
Which makes it so you kind of have to plan what you‚Äôre going to do the next day because often times if you don‚Äôt do that then you just won‚Äôt be able to do it because of the time constraints
Days being very short also makes it so you have to constantly be making new plans every few minutes which gives you a sense of constantly achieving something

The game also has a strong social element where you can literally marry and kiss some npcs (only those that are marked as single) and even player characters if you aren‚Äôt playing alone
For me the enjoyment would have to come from figuring out how to get as much money as quickly as possible which I didn‚Äôt get to experience since I was playing with someone who already had 150 hours in this game
I can name the following main gameplay reasons to play this game:
Figuring out how to get as much money as possible (and all the systems associated with this process, so treating the game kind of like Factorio)

‚ÄúSocial‚Äù element (interactions with 28 unique villager npcs which include but are not limited to talking, trading, helping, dating)
Collection/completionism (I have heard that the steam achievments in this game are among the hardest to complete due to how long that would take, and there is a museum with relic items you can find in the game)
You private property building/decorating (explanation probably not needed, I can note that this was the first time when I didn‚Äôt feel overwhelmed by my options)

Fishing (You may snicker at me for making this into it‚Äôs own category, especially since this doesn‚Äôt really offer anything objectively unique - this is part completionism, part money making and part helping npcs.
Yet I have seen fishing in almost every game I have played recently I start to suspect that there really is a demand for specifically ‚Äúfishing‚Äù being in the game, which by the way while seems odd to me should be understandable. 
The fishing minigame in stardew valley itself is similar to other fishing minigames you have played, for example the Genshin one.) 

And lastly the cave/mining gameplay (it is the familiar loop of breaking blocks and killing enemies and finding valuable items from time to time, with the cave changing enemies and scenery every so often, making the player curious what the next biome will be like. This cave gameplay is fairly different from rest of the game which made it stand out to me.)
There were other gameplay loops like the incredibly challenging arcade minigames but I just didn‚Äôt consider them being a big enough part to include as a reason to play the game 
But yeah if you end up not liking any of these in the context of the time management element + the interactions with npc then you have no reason to like the game
But you will more likely end up enjoying one or more and enjoy this game!

Stardew Valley has been a long time beloved game of mine and honestly I can see myself playing it for years to come! I love how easily moddable it is, it makes replayability so much more interesting with new npcs or mechanics modded in. The preexisting game is really fun and gets me hooked for at least a week at a time, and I'm always learning a new thing about the game in any media I see of it or just playing on my own. If you're looking for a cozy farming sim, stardew valley is definately a top 10 choice!

‚ÄúI gotta tell ya, it was perfect. 
Perfect.
Everything.
Down to the last, minute details.‚Äù

While the game seems quite simple at first, it becomes quite vast and complex while still letting you play at your own pace. There is a lot of player agency and nothing is forced onto the player, even farming. despite it being one of its main advertised features. Build a massive farming tycoon, mine rocks and ores to your hearts content, or fish for every penny, you can do whatever you want, whenever. 

You start with simple farming, then work your way to foraging, unlocking new areas that allow mining and dungeon crawling/fighting, to even exploring a whole new custom map near the end of the game. You are consistently hit with new content, new events, and new things to do. While it can be a little daunting or frustrating at times because of no explanation, when you do find secrets or figure out puzzles it's not just rewarding in dopamine, but you typically get unique rewards that make you more efficient.

Thanks for not pandering to the crazy people Eric. I also hope your friend was able to get over the petty drama and do something they are passionate about. 
Good luck on your next release!

One lovely golden autumn day I felt like playing something cozy for a change from action roguelikes and such. Stardew Valley was already in my library, but frankly I tried it before and at that time it didn't grow on me and I quit in less than a couple hours. But this time the mood was just right for countryside escape and do farming.

Needless to say that the game is charming and quickly sets you to the country life daily routine loop. I enjoyed the early game progression. Learning farming tricks and optimizing your returns was fun. I wanted to get sprinklers so bad, that became my motivation to go caving to get crafting materials. Fishing is lots of fun too when you get a grasp on that mini game.

The game unfortunately breaks the spell of peaceful country life, at least for me, and offers you industrial scale farming development as you get over a certain threshold of gold on your account. The crops yield enormous incomes, forcing you to do something else or don't, because you have all you need. Except new resources that you can find in new caves, which is the opposite of what I wanted when coming to play a cozy game.

One thing that bugged me the most in the game was the time limit. You have so much you can do during an in-game day, so as in real life. But it always kept me frustrated that I cannot fit farming, foraging and social quests in one day. So I eventually gave up and focused just on farming, occasionally going to caves and fishing, and I totally neglected all the social life aspect of the game. Though somehow I got married on that hippie artist girl.

Despite a few negative sentiments, I would say it's a great game. The endless sandbox game is not for everyone, but if you want to take a break an explore cozy games and some cottage-core aesthetics, you'll be treated with at least 40 hours of great time. I spent a bit over 80 hours in it, and lived up until mid-fall of the second in-game year. Built a huge farm, built max size house, got married, finished all quests in community center, became millionaire. But after I achieved all that I didn't have motivation to wait for certain someone to get to see me and evaluate my achievements. But it doesn't mean the game is bad, it's just the thing about sandbox games, you play it for as long as you need it.

I absolutely adore this game. Use the wiki if you get lost, and know you aren't supporting triple-a garbage. Thank you, concerned ape, for making the single greatest little farming/dating/borderline horror game I've ever had the pleasure of picking up.

I've only played Stardew Valley for a couple of hours, and it's already been a journey! The game is incredibly charming, but I'm clearly a natural disaster when it comes to farming life. My first night, I lost track of time, got caught in the rain, and just... passed out right there on the ground. The next morning, I got a letter informing me that "unconsciousness is dangerous" and a bill for the emergency services that found me! I didn't even know that was possible. On day two, I was determined to clear the land around my house. I got a little too enthusiastic with my axe, chopped one too many trees, and collapsed from exhaustion right on my own doorstep. Cue another letter and another medical bill. My farmer is a liability, and I've earned more debt at this point. Despite my character's apparent death wish, I'm having a blast. The fact that the game has these funny, forgiving consequences for failure makes it feel alive and lighthearted. I'm learning to manage my energy and time, and the loop of "work, nearly die, get a bill, repeat" is weirdly addictive. It's a cozy, funny, and surprisingly deep game, even if my bank account in Pelican Town is already in the red. Can't wait to see what other trouble I can get into lol!
Just a well rounded and fun time. Peaceful gaming at it's peak!

Stardew Valley has immaculate progression. In the beginning, all you can do is water 15 parsnips then pass out for the day. Then you unlock the mines, find copper. Use copper to upgrade tools, chop more to build coops. Use eggs as gifts. Unlock more recipes when you level up and makes friends. Several seasons later, you're managing several plots of land, have a kickbutt sword and are the proud owner of a pig named Gelatin.

The cyclical nature between different portions of the game keeps gameplay refreshing and progression constantly on the horizon as a motivation. It's a fantastic formula, and the developer has poured enough interesting items and areas to last you a hundred hours.

On my second farm, and this time I just reached perfection. I absolutely love this game - one of my favourites of all time. The challenges increase over time, and allows some change of focus as you go along. The core is the farm and local community though, and has so many nice touches in it.

The perfection ending is also a nice touch, with the mid-game 2 year evaluation also a good stopping point. Some games the ending is an anti-climax, but this one made it feel like you achieved something.

For new starters - play at your own pace, start off with farming just a small area for a few days as you get used to it. And do not sell the stone or wood you clear - you will need it soon!

100 hours in... and I LOVE this game. There is SO much progression in this game, it's unlike any other 2d indie game out there. The game has not only an amazing community in-game, but also on the Reddit forums. As I reached hour 100 of the game, I completed the Community Center! Doing so, has helped me progress in the game and is also a really good way of playing the game to it's fullest. I even have a gf! (soon to be wife lol) There is plenty that this game offers, anywhere from fishing, to killing a boss 100 levels deep, I could not recommend this game enough. Just beware.. it gets REALLY addicting.

There's no shortage of things to do in the game and the content self-expands (ex. new seeds are offered as crops to grow each season). Fishing is difficult and winter lasts way too long for me, but those are personal preferences. There is a glitch in the game that has never been fixed, so be aware: during the Easter Egg Hunt event, if you're playing multiplayer/co-op, only one of you may participate. If anyone else does too, the game freezes after the timer ends and everyone must restart the day, losing all progress they may have made. Also, pleeeaasseee implement a quest marker! I'm constantly failing quests and wasting days because I can't find people, and as a new player I couldn't find my way around the town very well.  But those are really the only complaints I have. It may seem like a lot but the massive content provided by the game far outweighs the cons, so I would recommend giving it a shot. (I got my husband into it and he usually hates games like this.)

Although I do not have many hours on steam, I have collective of 400 hours on my nintendo and another 200 on my xbox. I have not been very focused on this game since I have bought my personal computer, but I would love to share my opinion and hopefully convince someone to buy this game. 

This game is very diverse and you can choose whatever path you see fit for you. Either you enjoy finding out about characters and dialog in the game, or you rather simply plant crops and fight in the mines. Whatever you do, there is not pressure on what you do in this game. You can let your creativity flow with your farm and how you do things. Personally, I start crunching numbers and get very locked on the money aspect of the game and love love love the characters and their stories. I have been a fan of this game for years and I still find small details, easter eggs, or new things I can do. This game is worth the twenty dollars; everyone should try to play this game at least once.

After 1100 hours in Stardew Valley, I can confidently say this game is a masterpiece of cozy immersion and creative freedom. I‚Äôve been playing since it first launched and watching it evolve over the years has been nothing short of magical. What started as a charming farming sim has grown into a rich, expansive world that rewards curiosity, experimentation, and emotional investment.
The updates have been phenomenal. Each one feels like a love letter to the community. From multiplayer to new farm layouts, expanded storylines, quality-of-life improvements, and even endgame content like Ginger Island, ConcernedApe has consistently added depth without compromising the game‚Äôs soul. The 1.6 update in particular brought a fresh wave of excitement with new festivals, dialogue, and mod support that makes replaying feel brand new.
Replayability is off the charts. Every farm layout nudges you toward a different playstyle. There‚Äôs no wrong way to play and no pressure to optimize unless you want to. I‚Äôve restarted countless times and each run feels distinct. The seasonal rhythm, the subtle storytelling, the freedom to decorate and design! it all combines into a game that never gets stale. <3

Ingredients For the Pumpkin Pie:

    ‚ñ¢ 1 9-inch Homemade pie crust , or store-bought, deep dish, unbaked
    ‚ñ¢ 3/4 cup granulated sugar
    ‚ñ¢ 1 teaspoon ground cinnamon
    ‚ñ¢ 1/2 teaspoon salt
    ‚ñ¢ 1/2 teaspoon ground ginger
    ‚ñ¢ 1/4 teaspoon ground cloves
    ‚ñ¢ 2 large eggs
    ‚ñ¢ 15 ounce can canned pumpkin or fresh pumpkin puree
    ‚ñ¢ 12 ounce can evaporated milk

Instructions
 

    Preheat oven to 425 degrees F.
    In a large bowl beat the eggs and pumpkin together.  In a separate bowl, combine the sugar, cinnamon, salt, ginger and cloves, and add to pumpkin mixture.
    Gradually stir in the evaporated milk. Carefully pour mixture into unbaked pie shell*.
    Bake at 425 degrees F for for 15 minutes. Reduce temperature to 350¬∞ F; bake for 40 to 50 minutes longer, or until the pie is set. Check for doneness by giving the pie a gentle wiggle. The center may jiggle just a tiny bit. It will continue to set up as it cools. Or, it is done when a sharp knife inserted in center comes out clean.
    Cool completely on a wire cooling rack. Serve immediately with whipped cream and caramel pecan topping, if desired.

While my hour count is not a abysmal on here as it is on other platforms, I shall leave a review anyways. This was one of the first games I bought with my own money at the ripe ole age of 12. At first, I didn't enjoy it, I didn't understand it. Then I revisited about a year or two later and became obsessed. The consistent loop of farming, mining, and monster killing drew me in. The pleasureful grind sucked me into pure unbridled obsession. The multiple ways of approaching this game kept me coming. When I finally got a PC, the options just opened up. The amount of versatility in modding and creativity is captivating.
The romantic interests are all unique and have wonderful story lines. Each character you meet in this game has their own unique charm that anyone would keep coming back to. Not to mention the update support, with ConcernedApe consistently coming back despite working on another banger of a video game. This game fundamentally changed my life, it carried me through the quarantine, and I wouldn't have it any other way. If you have the spare 15 bucks, please buy this game, trust me it's worth it. You can get hundreds of hours out of this game, even without going full completionist with the achievement and perfection. 10/10 love this game would recommend to anyone listening.

I've been playing Stardew for a long time now, both on Playstation and PC, and I gotta say it's up there in my favorite games. The vanilla gameplay's really fun, and modding is incredibly easy once you figure out the basics.

Pros-
-You can spend literal days of real time playing before you reach a peak, and even then, you can play infinitely longer
-Graphics are cute and insanely well made
-Each save can be completely different from the last, allowing for each replay to feel unique
-The music's a vibe, I mainly fish in the early game for money, and I'll end up just sitting there and enjoying the music while fishing. It really does help me relax
-Gameplay's a little repetitive at times, but overall I've never had any issues. In fact, in some cases, I think the repetition can be nice
-Multiplayer works great. I've probably got at least 5 multiplayer slots and have never had any issues with lag, frame drops, or any performance related things. At least to my memory.
-As mentioned before, modding is easy once you get the basics out of the way, and some mods are really neat. I personally recommend SVE since it adds a billion new things to do and a handful of new characters.
-Abigail.
-The town feels cozy. Plus, it's not too hard to navigate around the map, and even in SVE where a lot of locations change/get added, it still feels easy to figure out where you are at any given time

Cons-
-Early game's a bit of a chore. You're given 1 hotbar to work with, and your first backpack costs 2k gold. It's not hard to get that much, but you also have to factor in your other tools and crops.
-I know this one's technically optional, but the Introduction quest is just a pain to do. I'll spend like 2 days worth of time just trying to find every NPC to say "hi".
-Developers, let me date Caroline and my life is yours.
-I don't know if this is really a pro or a con, but EXP is... Interesting. You can theoretically play for as many in-game years as you want (to my knowledge anyway), but your skill levels cap out at 10. Meaning you could theoretically max out every skill by Year 1, and be stagnant for the rest of the game. I personally wish it was a bit higher to make up for the time you can play for, but I know some people would definitely disagree.
-Joja's entire existence is a con.

Overall though I can't recommend this game enough. I'd say once you hit Summer of Year 1, things really start ramping up. You'll usually have your backpacks, a good fishing rod, maybe your tools upgraded, and a good chunk of cash by then. If you play it right, playing with multiple people with a shared money load can even make things SO much better. Because you don't have to worry about "wait you stole my crops that I paid for and planted", because the money you get on return goes into your shared account anyway.

Stardew Valley is, at this point, a classic and there's very little I can say in this review that hasn't been said thousands of times already. It is probably the best indie game you will play, here is why.

1. It's has GREAT music and when I say that I mean it. I mean the music is like the best part of the game, I play the game because of the music.

2. The gameplay is Awesome too. The gameplay is great on keyboard & mouse and controller. (Just don't play it on mobile.)

3. last is the story. the story is amazing, you play as this farmer who lives in pelican town and is inheriting a farm from your grandfather. You have to restore the farm and make it your own.

Those are three reasons you should play Stardew Valley! I have played with my brother, cousin, and mom. Like i said this is the best Indie game you will play in you gaming hobby!

Alright, listen up. You're probably burned out from getting teabagged by 12-year-olds in shooters or grinding dailies in some soulless MMO. Your soul needs a vacation. Your brain needs a hug. What you need, my friend, is Stardew Valley.

Forget everything you know about farming sims being "boring." This game is a masterpiece of pure, unadulterated dopamine. It's the video game equivalent of a warm blanket and a cup of hot chocolate.

The Grind is... Actually Fun?

The core loop is genius. You start with a dump of a farm, overrun with trees and rocks. It looks like a scene from a post-apocalyptic movie. But then you get your rusty tools, and the magic begins. "Just one more day" becomes your mantra. You'll find yourself saying, "Okay, just gonna water my crops, pet my chickens, maybe go fishing... wait, it's 2 AM in-game and I'm risking passing out to catch one more carp."

Before you know it, you're not just a farmer. You're a artisanal mayonnaise tycoon, a master angler, a legendary monster slayer in the mines, and the town's #1 matchmaker. The skill progression is so satisfying it should be illegal.

Content for Decades

The amount of stuff to do is absolutely bonkers. This isn't just a farming game. It's a:

¬∑ Dating Sim: Can you woo the goth elf boy or the moody writer? You betcha.
¬∑ Dungeon Crawler: The mines are no joke! Pack some snacks and a good sword.
¬∑ Town Restoration Project: Rebuild the community center and stick it to the corporate Joja Mart. Feels good, man.
¬∑ Fishing RPG: The fishing minigame is a whole vibe and I will fight anyone who says otherwise.

The Verdict: 10/10, A Perfect Comfort Game

Stardew Valley is a legendary indie gem, the kind of game you'll still have installed years from now. It's a world that feels alive, thanks to its charming characters and their own little stories. ConcernedApe, the solo dev behind this masterpiece, is an absolute GOAT for creating this and supporting it for so long.

TL;DR:
If you have even a single chill bone in your body,BUY THIS GAME. It's the ultimate palate cleanser, a time-sink you'll never regret, and honestly, cheaper than therapy. Just be warned: you'll start playing, look up at the clock, and realize you've been optimizing your crop layout for three real-life hours. Totally worth it.

See you at the Stardrop Saloon! Now, if you'll excuse me, I have to go give a pickle to my future vampire wife.

Stardew Valley is a charming indie farming simulator that combines relaxation with creativity. Players inherit a run-down farm and can grow crops, raise animals, mine for resources, and build relationships with townspeople. The pixel-art graphics and soothing music create a cozy, nostalgic atmosphere. What makes it special is the freedom.

Stardew Valley has been my favorite farming game for a good five years now. Having played through a new save on Steam and almost reaching perfection again at the time of writing this review, it's just as calming, fun, and open-ended as I remembered. As a gamer with the attention span and general gameplay interests of a caveman, it's pretty crazy that something that appears so mundane and simple at a surface level is one of the most addicting things I've ever played.

This game has been around long enough that the best it has to offer has already been parroted by tons of people, so I'll try to keep the things I love most pretty brief. Progression is perfect and moves at a pace that's simultaneously slow enough that the game always always feels relaxing, yet fast enough that all of the seasonal content the game has to offer returns semi-frequently and it's not quite as agonizing if you accidentally forget to/run out of time to do something during a certain season. NPC townsfolk are designed great, having unique schedules and interests and pretty engaging storylines for the most part. There's a ton of ways you can make money, and with the right setup any of them can be extremely profitable, which makes the gameplay fundamentally super open-ended. That paired with the sheer diversity of things you can do in a single year cycle and the (SPOILER FOR ENDGAME AREA) [spoiler]giant distant island with a colossal amount of unique content you can access late in the game[/spoiler] gives this game a pretty insane longevity that provides hundreds of hours of engagement, and ensures that there's a dozen other projects you can focus on if you can't finish something season-specific.

It's been said by many already, but I can concur that this game has something for everyone. Tons of avenues of farming and ranching for whatever playstyle you have the most fun with, well-designed and fun combat that can be challenging but rarely feels like you're unfairly screwed over, open-ended building and different farm layouts that can allow for breathtakingly beautiful farms, tons of varied NPCs of different age groups you can choose to make friends with or pursue romantically (or not, you can be a sigma lone wolf too, with zero consequences), cross-platform co-op if you'd like to play with a friend or partner, Steam Deck compatibility (which I can't comment further on as I don't have one), and some fun lore that you by no means need to care about at all to enjoy the game but also adds some very welcome charm and mystique to the world if it does interest you, all for the frankly stupid price of only $15 USD. There are very few games that provide this level of content and quality with an indie pricetag, and it's fantastic that we have a charming and relaxing life sim in that boat, as a majority of them tend to lean towards being fast, fun, and high-octane action/adventure/platformer titles. 

There's a million other things to gush about, but I'll leave it at that so as to not spoil anything for anyone. It's worth mentioning I don't play with mods apart from a few small quality-of-life things, but a single browse through Nexus will make it obvious there's a pretty wild modding community working diligently to enhance the game even further. This game is an unbelievably good value for $15, even going on sale occasionally, and comes packaged with so much varied content it's highly unlikely you wouldn't enjoy the game (though I think it also does a good job playing enough of its cards in the first two hours that you'll know very well if this game simply isn't for you and you want to refund it). I can't do anything but strongly recommend giving Stardew a try. The amount of positive reception it continues to get almost a decade after release and its stagnant Overwhelmingly Positive rating on this platform says enough; this game is WELL worth your money. Thank you for helping me through some of the hardest times of my life with your funny little farming game, Mr. Ape.

This game absolutely captivates me. It's such a rewarding experience, especially on the Steam Deck. There's genuine depth to explore, wrapped in this wonderfully cozy atmosphere that manages to be both contemplative and engaging without feeling tedious. What draws me most is the freedom; you genuinely control your path forward, choosing what matters to you. I grew up with the original Harvest Moon games like Back to Nature and Harvest Moon 64, and this feels like a spiritual successor that honors those classics while pushing beyond them.

What makes it special is how it balances competing moods: there's this inherent warmth and charm, yet underneath runs something more ominous and unsettling that lurks just beneath the surface that gives it quite the realism factor. That tonal complexity; cozy yet shadowed, welcoming yet mysterious, creates something that feels both comforting and genuinely unsettling at times. The whole experience carries this elegant equilibrium where no single element overwhelms the others. 

Beyond the game itself, I really respect the developer behind it. ConcernedApe embodies a thoughtfulness and integrity that's increasingly rare, and supporting creators like that matters to me.

This game is a perfect combination of a zen farming simulator and an rpg adventure game. You have the choice of at least 5 different pass times every day (Farming, mining, fishing, character interaction, exploring...) and this game is much more than what people assume to be just another over saturated farming game. I would highly recommend to anyone who also enjoys Minecraft, Terraria, or other farming sims. Beautiful artwork, an addictive game design, and a beautiful soundtrack. Truly a masterpiece of a game.

Stardew Valley is an incredible sandbox style farming simulator. It has many opportunities for creativity, and as such, it is easy to have many unique saves across the game. Highly recommend.

This game is basically a warm hug in pixel form - the GOAT of cozy games that every farming indie title dreams of being. No timers, no pressure, just pure freedom to do whatever you want. It spoils you with little rewards, easter eggs, amazing soundtracks, and funny moments with its NPCs. Although there is an optional "true ending", you‚Äôll always find a way to keep playing long after that. I have 900+ hours, and I still get excited whenever someone suggests playing it. Plus, it‚Äôs perfect to play with your partner or friends. Love it to bits!

Stardew Valley is one of those rare games that just stays with you. I went all the way and 100%‚Äôd it, and for some reason I still open it from time to time ‚Äî sometimes just to walk around and listen to the rain, sometimes to go fight slimes in the mines like it‚Äôs a life-or-death mission. There‚Äôs something therapeutic about almost dying to a dust spirit at 2 AM.

But what really sets the game apart is the people. The characters feel like they‚Äôve got actual lives and issues. Abigail? Eats rocks and somehow makes it cool. Haley starts off like she runs a high school mean girl cult, but ends up surprisingly decent. Shane has the emotional range of an actual human being who's seen some stuff. They‚Äôre flawed in ways that make sense, and that makes Pelican Town feel incredibly real.

And then there‚Äôs ConcernedApe! one person making an entire game of this scale and heart? No cut corners, no cash grabs, no ‚Äúseason pass.‚Äù Just layered design, care for the craft, and free updates even years later. The guy‚Äôs a workhorse.

Oh, and one personal tip: Don't play it with your spouse. Stardew has a weird power. One minute you're just choosing which crops to plant, next minute you're low-key angry at your partner for messing up the chests. I almost got divorced over a virtual chicken coop. Not kidding.

All in all, it's calm, deep, and has more soul than most games released today. Easily one of the best experiences I‚Äôve ever had in gaming.

Although I would recommend this game to play because it's iconic, I cannot say it's great. It's pretty empty, graphics are bad, once you watched all the cutscenes with npcs, there's nothing to do at all. So it's good for a one-time playthtough, it's definitely not the game I will come back to.
excellent game

I still can‚Äôt decide if I‚Äôm playing a cozy farming game or slowly building a cult of villagers who love my mayonnaise.

You start off escaping the soul-crushing corporate grind to fix up your grandpa‚Äôs old farm‚Äîand suddenly you‚Äôre knee-deep in crops, fishing at 2 a.m., and crying because you missed the flower dance again. It‚Äôs wholesome, chaotic, and weirdly personal.

The magic of Stardew is how every little thing matters. You plant, water, harvest, upgrade, fall in love, mine until you pass out, then do it all again. The seasons change, your farm evolves, and somehow you start caring more about your pixel cows than your real-life responsibilities.

The villagers? Absolute characters. Some are sweet, some are disasters, and all of them will judge your life choices. But over time, you build bonds that feel real‚Äîand suddenly, giving Shane a beer every day feels like emotional support.

After 180 hours, I‚Äôve got ancient fruit wine money, a wife, two kids, and still get excited when it rains.

‚≠ê 10/10 ‚Äì Cozy therapy disguised as a farming sim.
üêî ‚ÄúOne more day,‚Äù I said‚Ä¶ 180 hours ago.

The game never becomes boring thanks to its endless possibilities: farming, mining, crafting, fishing, building relationships, exploring, decorating, and uncovering secrets. Concerned Ape is the GOAT for continuing to update this game for free for nearly a decade since it came out--recommended purely on that, even if I personally don't really love this game, probably due to some undiagnosed mental issue I have. The stamina bar and the timer mechanics are just too stressful for me. There are a couple other mechanics that compound this frustration. Like, I want to do good by my Grandpa (who is the one you inherit the farm from, who ostensibly comes back after your second year to judge how well you've done. But thinking about having a farm that makes him proud, and also about finishing the community bundles (which have many things that can only be done during certain seasons/conditions) makes me feel like I constantly have to meticulously plan out my week, making sure not to waste a single day. That kind of gameplay can be fun, but it feels at odds with the vibe the rest of the game is trying to curate. 

IDK though, so many people love this game, so like I said I think my experience is probably due to the specific weird-ass way my brain works, so I'd probably still give it a go.

"Stardew Valley is the best farming game ever!" is a sentence I‚Äôve heard and read A LOT. I wish I had something else to say, but damn, Stardew Valley really is the best farming game ever.

It's not just the amazing pixel art, the relaxing music, the beautiful colors of everything, the changing seasons, the various crafts, the diversity of the gameplay. It's getting to know the villagers, their personalities, starting to get attached and love them deeply. Remembering their favorite dishes, their stories, discovering their heart events. It's helping your community, gifting your homemade products, loving your pets and animals, watering your crops, fixing the community center. It's reading too many Reddit forums, going everyday to the wiki, trying to get all the achievements, playing and laughing with friends, and finally succeeding at closing the hell of Joja. Playing Stardew Valley is really just like drinking a hot chocolate inside, watching the rain fall by the window.

Thank you, ConcernedApe! :)

The ultimate chill game.
Stardew Valley is honestly the best game for anyone who just wants to relax and discover new things at their own pace. Every playthrough feels different. I‚Äôm still learning new stuff every time I play, even after hours in the game. It‚Äôs cozy, peaceful, and somehow never gets old.

For something made by one person, it‚Äôs insanely impressive. ConcernedApe built a whole world that just pulls you in, from the farming and fishing to the characters and the music.

If you want a game that helps you unwind but still keeps you curious, this is it.

This game is absolutely amazing, specially having in mind that it was originally made by Concerned Ape instead of a huge company. 

The story itself isn't quite amusing, but the whole game has an energy that simply just drags you in. The whole concept of inheriting a farm in the middle of nowhere and deciding to go there moved by the feeling of emptyness in your life is already calling. Also, I love the friendship mechanics and the fact that you can marry the bachellors; although some 14 heart events are boring. Besides, some festivities or special events (like Christmas and The Egg Hunt) are really exciting because they are more interactive. I would like The Egg Hunt more if the locations of the eggs changed every year though.

However, I must say that the game gets kind of repetitive if you're playing alone. I highly recomend you to play online, it's more thrilling and you can't predict what will happen through the day. Also, the skull caverns are kind of boring (in my opinion), and for others is the thing they hate the most about the game.

I love every aspect of SDV. At first, it was somewhat confusing when I first started and I forgot about it about 6 months after purchasing it. Then, I had a break from school and made an attempt of playing it again. So, I did a few village tasks, explored the map, foraged, and whatever else I could fit in a day. I met the villagers, got to know their likes and dislikes, their stories, and I became invested with the game. You could could virtually do everything from farming, fishing, crafting, exploring and mining caves, fighting monsters, etc. It has multiplayer, too. You would (almost) never run out of things to do in the game. All in all, I highly recommend giving this a shot.

Some people may have told you that Stardew Valley is a chill game about farming and making friends. Someone might have told you that this is an easy going, relaxing game that can be enjoyed by anyone, even those who don't normally play video games. Those people were wrong. Stardew Valley is not really a game at all; it is a mirror, reflecting within it the darkness of the human condition, and my own inability to escape it. 

At the time of this review, I have logged 400 hours into this game across platforms. I have completed the community center in it's entirety, and I have perfectly optimized my farm for brutal efficiency. I make millions of dollars every season, and, for good reason, l continue pushing just to see how grotesque my industrial landscape can become. I have never spoken to a single member of the town who cannot benefit me monetarily in my personal quest for power. 

This game may be relaxed for some, but for me, it is war. There will be no item left unpurchased, no crop left ungrown, and no slime left unslain. I have become Death, destroyer of worlds. If you share a desire for ruthless expansion and power, this game is for you. If you just want to have a cute little farm and role-play a simple but idyllic rural fantasy, this game is also for you. If you value your mental health, or maintaining productivity, this game may not be for you.

"When you gaze long into the abyss, the abyss gazes also into you." - Friedrich Nietzsche

If you want to get lost in a world of curiosities, exploration, community, and fun, THIS IS THE GAME FOR YOU! I freaking love this game. Its part farming sim, part mystery story, part Sims style game play all wrapped into one. I got this game when I was early on in my gaming years and it has been one of the few games that has stuck with me for a long time. It can be exciting and chill, adventurous and calm, the things you can do in the game can fit whatever vibe you're feeling on a given day. Truth be told, I actually learned a lot of life lessons in this game. Call me crazy, but I feel like God used this game to teach me the value of patience, and the value of what you can get done in one day. You can't do everything you want in one day, but you can get one step closer to your goal by taking just one more step everyday. This is a game where you get what you put in. Commit to the game for the long haul and it is so worth seeing it to the end. I HIGHLY recommend this game!

I am still constantly blown away that a SINGLE MAN came out of the woodwork, dropped this absolute banger of a game that managed to surpass and redefine the genre it was inspired by. 

This game took Harvest Moon out into the woods, and absolutely took it to school.  It's very telling that while that series manages to vomit out a new entry (Both from the original developer, and the cheap knock-offs using the brand name) they can't even touch the success of the brave little indie game that could.

Janky? Yes. 
Fun? Without a doubt. 

A rare indie gem that is a perfect 10 for what it does well.  This game DEMANDS to be played, and I'd be actually shocked if anyone was reading this review, because WHO HASN'T PLAYED THIS YET?

GET IT.

This is such a great game. There are a ton of things I love about it.

First up, as a full-time engineer in a high-stress job, this is a relaxing video game. It's so relaxing that it often helps me destress after long workdays and really helps me chill out.

Second, it's beautiful. The pixel art is enjoyable to look at.

Third, it's got a ton of replayability. It doesn't really "get old" like lots of other games once you've beaten them.

And finally, there's a massive amount of mods to improve the experience. After you've beaten the game a couple times, try out the mods! There are a ton of amazing mods that let you add all sorts of great things into the game. Can't really ask for more!

Stardew Valley is one of those rare games that feels both peaceful and deeply rewarding. What starts as a simple farming simulator quickly becomes a story about community, growth, and finding meaning in the little things. Every player‚Äôs experience feels personal ‚Äî whether you‚Äôre rebuilding the town, raising animals, fishing at sunset, or getting to know the charming, sometimes mysterious villagers.

The pixel art is warm and nostalgic, yet full of life. The soundtrack perfectly matches each season, adding a gentle emotional rhythm to your farm‚Äôs daily routine. What really stands out, though, is how much freedom the game gives you. You can focus on crops, mining, fishing, crafting, decorating your home, or even starting a family ‚Äî and none of these paths ever feel forced.

It‚Äôs easy to lose hours just living in this world. The balance between calm routine and slow discovery makes Stardew Valley not just a game, but a comforting escape. Even after hundreds of hours, it still feels alive thanks to updates and a passionate community of modders.

Verdict:
‚≠ê 10/10 ‚Äî Stardew Valley isn‚Äôt just a farming game. It‚Äôs a peaceful journey about life, choice, and finding joy in simple things. :3

I've been playing Stardew Valley since I'm alone. I marry Haley, doing as much as I can do in the game, before I left her and the Stardew. Six years later, I have a family. My daughter is now 5 years old. She played Stardew Valley for the first time on steam family sharing account, with joy. Then I even switch back to my save file, to meet Haley again. I introduce Haley's existence to my daughter without my wife killing me. I feel the fulfillment, my imagination friend is in contact with my real family. So, Stardew Valley is a very good game for family and child development, I must say.

One of my favourite games of all time and one of a handful of games I have played at least a few hours of every year since I first bought it. I own it on 3 platforms. 

There's something unbelievably comforting about Stardew Valley. The bright and happy pixel art and cozy setting evoke a feeling of home. But Stardew Valley sings because it's systems are deep and satisfying. Farming is the most basic building block of the game, but the mining, crafting, foraging, fishing and combat systems all offer a great distraction from the sometimes repetitive nature the game. 

The fantastic world and playful character writing are a big part of what keep me hooked on this game too, and decorating my house in weird and wonderful ways is as much of a joy 4 years after getting the game as it was the first time I booted up. 

And lastly, I have a dog to feed.

Stardew Valley is one of the few truly cozy games that gets it right. It lets you move at your own pace without constantly pushing you forward with endless quests or objectives. Everything about it is simple and balanced. The charm lies in its calm design and the way it avoids trying too hard. The NPCs are kind, grounded, and genuinely pleasant, without being extra or tryhard. It‚Äôs a wholesome, well-balanced experience that feels authentic and relaxing. And I love my black cat, Plum.

A very cool game about farming and doing a lot of goodies around the community. There are a lot of interesting regions to explore, lots of activities to do besides farming such as fishing, foraging, mining, and of course talking with all the characters within!

Overall it's a very pleasant experience that you can do at your own pace, with or without other people. There are plenty of customization options and ways to decorate your farm, its surroundings and other areas. If you're really keen on doing more than this game already has to offer, there is also a pretty sizeable modding scene.

[h1]This game is a masterpiece of art,[/h1] [h3]but let me start off just by saying;[/h3]
There is no drug that can recreate the pure euphoria of opening a window, cozying up in a blanket, and sipping some delicious tea (or other warm drink of your choice) while enjoying the gorgeous scenery this wonderful game has to offer. There's so many things to do; Farming crops is a great way to make money and all, but for being classified as what I would call a "farming game", there's so, so much more to do than simply farm crops and take care of your animals. Relationships with characters [b][i]**really**[/i][/b] feel like they matter, but even still, the game doesn't particularly FORCE you to engage with barely anyone.


[h3]Do you like dating simulators?[/h3] This game has a mechanic where you can marry certain characters, all with their own little playable stories and cutscenes that make them feel so much more real and alive. 

[h3]More of a fighter?[/h3] The caves (and later on, the Skull Cavern) are packed with enemies to fight and treasures to find. 

[h1]Do you enjoy giving as much money to a soulless, greedy corporation that you want to distance yourself as much as possible from?[/h1] [h3]Well... you're not gonna fuckin' believe this...[/h3]

[h2]There is genuinely something in this game for anyone and everyone.[/h2] Anyone who classifies this as "just another farming game" is missing out on so much in the indie video game scene. The art and sprites are gorgeous, animations are smooth and clean, but not so much so that it feels weird for a pixel game. 

Frankly, I don't rate games very often, but I just can't help myself with Stardew Valley. I've played countless, countless hours on my switch, from the toilet to the Doctors office, its so easy to just pull out and play whenever, wherever, for however long. 
9.97/10. Wonderful job, ConcernedApe.

I have to be honest. I refunded Stardew Valley twice. At first, it felt strange to me, even artistically, with its pixelated style, and I didn‚Äôt give it the time it deserved. The third time I bought it, someone showed me how to actually play it and what it was truly about. The truth is, there‚Äôs no 'right' way to play Stardew Valley. You can simply do the quests, or just relax and watch your crops grow.

Now, I see Stardew Valley through different eyes. It‚Äôs simply beautiful, and I treasure it. Its story, its details, everything. I later found out it was made by a single person, and that completely changed my perspective. That realization was mind-blowing.

I‚Äôve been playing it with some friends recently, and now I truly cherish it. Stardew Valley is a masterpiece.

I don't think a game has ever had such a hold on me (except maybe Skyrim).

Stardew Valley is THE GOLDEN STANDARD for the modern farming sim/RPG for many reasons: the gameplay, the setting, the story, the characters, the music... I lost myself in Pelican Town a couple of hours every day after work for weeks on end.

I thoroughly enjoyed my progression from a humble gardener to a multimillionaire in my road to perfection in over 4 in-game years. It's filled with small victories, every new fish you catch, every profession you unlock, every build you commission, all the expansions and installations in your fields, your artisan enterprise, your social life, this game rewards you and encourages you to go further all the time.

I have a few nitpicks, nothing deal-breaking, just little "ugh" moments I experienced here and there:

- Forced socialization:
Why do I have to max-heart everyone in town? Plus, the friendship decay (especially with animals) is too punishing in a game aspect that's already too grindy. If that hoe Marnie sold an autopetter, that would be great. And btw, why are romanceables all young adults? We need an option for Zaddy Gus and muscle mommy Robin.

- Inventory clutters too fast:
Especially with the various qualities of fish and forageables. If tools didn't take up inventory space, that would be a huge QoL improvement (in 1.7 Eric, please?).

- The dinosaurs:
Pepper Rex are the only element that broke my suspension of disbelief. They feel so out of place in this picturesque rural setting. An eyesore.

- Unconsequential story elements:
Like the mayor‚Äôs affair and his golden statue. Robin's unhappy marriage. Community center re-abandoned right after restoration...

So, after reaching perfection, unlocking all 49 achievements (I totally didn't mod the 2 cheevos for Journey of the Prairie King),

my final rating for Stardew is a resounding, unapologetic 19/20. Stardew is a lifestyle!

Bought this game in 2019 and tried dozens of times to get into it.  Never could.  First missed deadline or accidentally mined farm space and I was out.  For some reason in late 2025 I pick it up on the steam deck and it gets me good.  I can not stop playing this game.  Slow day at work = Stardew Valley.  Girlfriend out and about = Stardew Valley.  Die early in a round of another game = Stardew Valley.  Etc etc.  I firmly believe that this game is among the greatest games ever made.  There is so much to do, so many people to romance, you can play with friends, you can mod it, the characters are all charming, the learning curve is just right, the list goes on.  It's the best $15 you'll ever spend.

Gameplay: 9,5/10
A cozy farming sim that has everything you need. Animals, crops, you can go to the mine or fishing, build relationshups with the townfolk and even adopt a cat. The latest update added a bunch of really enjoyable content without any extra cost, which is highly appreciated. One of the few games that actually got me hooked for more than 48h consecutively
Cost: 10/10
For the small amount that this game costs, I can just recommend to try it. I am 282 hours in, the mod-community on here is huge and I didn't even do the challenges provided by the community besides my achievement hunt. With more than 280h I still got enough content to cover another 300+ without additional cost
Achievements: 8,5/10
Overall the achievements are awesome. You got a little grind here and there, coordinate your farm and tactics and even have little sidequests to do so it doesn't repetitive easily. Would be a 10/10 if it wasn't for the achievement down below

Hardest achievement: "Fector's challenge"
This achievement ruined my last few moments in the valley. As the developer said himself, it is more difficult than it should be. With the savescumming method it is easier, but not fun in any way

The game is cute in the beginning but quickly becomes a repetitive slog. 

The game does not explain its mechanics at all, it depends completely on fan made content to make it playable for a new player. 

Fishing is the best example of course, fans of this game lol about how hard fishing is. But it's not only hard mechanically, in the beginning I couldn't understand what I was supposed to do at all. So if you stop fishing completely, Willy comes to you and asks you why you aren't fishing. If you say it's too hard, he gives you training rod, says he will give you a lesson. That just gives you one fishing level for free but still doesn't explain what you're supposed to do. It's like the dev clearly sees that fishing is just a mess in this game but decided to just shrug it off.
And you need to fish to progress the game...
This makes the game unbalanced because you progress all the other skills too fast compared to fishing, 

Then there's making friends with characters... It's mostly giving them gifts, doing their quests and hoping for a cut scene...
And finding these people in time to give them a gift without the wiki is near impossible - and you need to chase them around to give them gifts and finish their quests.
Ah, the mini quests, they start on the day you pick them up and you need to chase the character to close them on the next day, So you need to pick them up early enough to finish them on the same day you pick them up and then chase down the character who requested it the next day. 
There's so much timed stuff to keep track of, it gets stressful very quickly.
  
At least I lucked out with romance, chose Maru on looks alone in the beginning when I knew nothing about her because she's the only one that doesn't look like an anime reject (also funny how most of the romance options look like anime rejects and there's not a single Asian person in this game). Her personality is very pleasant and her story is neat. 

If someone is starting with this game, my one tip is ignore chasing the quests early on. It will only frustrate you.
And to never pick up Robin's hardwood quest before you get a horse. The horse lives in this sad shoddy stable that costs a lot of resources and he makes the game much more playable because you move faster on it. Hail the horsey.

Also, if you upgrade your foraging skills to collect double and then to get highest quality, piggies are the best. 

I'm a completionist, so I will try to restore the community centre but I might give up because of the fishing eventually because after days in game and hours irl of doing the fishing minigame, I still barely understand the mechanics of it, youtube tutorials help very little. 

Generally, if you think a farming game should be you running around all over the map trying to complete anything and forgetting 10 other things, and you find that fun, then this game is for you.

48 hours in. I started this with friends thinking it‚Äôd be a chill side game between tanking RPG sessions while I wait to upgrade my system. Now I‚Äôm managing crops, exploring caves, occasionally fighting monsters, and somehow invested in which villagers get my gifts. 

Linus is basically the MVP of the valley, lives in a tent, survives on berries, and somehow can afford to pay me three times the market price for a diamond. What a guy. 

It‚Äôs calm when it needs to be, chaotic when it‚Äôs not, and has that perfect ‚Äújust one more day‚Äù loop. You still get combat, loot, and progression, but it never feels stressful, just rewarding in a different way than my usual gory RPG grind.

Didn‚Äôt expect a farming sim to grab me like this, but here we are. I hope it keeps getting updates, because I‚Äôm not done.

‚≠ê 5/5 ‚Äî Came for the farm, stayed for the little victories.

‚≠êÔ∏è‚≠êÔ∏è‚≠êÔ∏è‚≠êÔ∏è‚≠êÔ∏è An Absolute Masterpiece ‚Äî Stardew Valley Shines Brighter Than the Sun!
Stardew Valley is, without question, one of the most heartwarming, beautifully crafted games ever made. From the very first moment you step off the bus into your overgrown little farm, the game wraps you in pure comfort and joy. üåæ‚ú®
Every element of Stardew Valley feels lovingly designed ‚Äî the soft pixel art, the gentle music that shifts with the seasons, and the sense of freedom that makes every day feel like your own story. You can farm, fish, mine, fall in love, build friendships, decorate, and explore ‚Äî all at your own pace. There‚Äôs no pressure, just a cozy rhythm that makes time disappear in the best possible way.
What makes it even more special is how alive the world feels. The villagers have unique personalities and stories, the festivals bring everyone together, and the changing seasons make the valley feel magical. There‚Äôs a deep sense of progress and reward, but also a warm, steady comfort that‚Äôs rare in games today.
Whether you‚Äôre chasing perfection or just watering your crops with a cup of tea in hand, Stardew Valley gives you peace, purpose, and endless joy. It‚Äôs more than just a game ‚Äî it‚Äôs a place that feels like home. üè°üíö
10/10 ‚Äî A timeless, soul-soothing adventure. I can‚Äôt recommend it enough.
