(Played on Steam Deck)

I tried. I really did. But this one just didn‚Äôt steep right.

Okay, confession time: I jumped into Stardew Valley because of the hype. It felt like everyone was talking about it - the cosy community‚Äôs ride-or-die farm sim. So I gave it a proper go. In fact, I played 35 hours. I kept dipping back in, hoping for the moment it would ‚Äúclick.‚Äù But honestly? That moment never came.

The core gameplay loop just didn‚Äôt land. I found myself stuck in a grind that felt more repetitive than rewarding. And while I normally enjoy slower, sim-style games, something about Stardew felt off. The farming was fine - but it never sparked joy. The rhythm of the days turned into a bit of a chore‚Ä¶ and not the comforting kind.

I struggled to connect with the characters. Their storylines felt generic, and I couldn‚Äôt get invested in the town‚Äôs social side the way so many others seem to. I know the heart of this game lies in its relationships, but I just didn‚Äôt feel much of a reason to care what anyone was up to.

As for the visuals - I get the nostalgic appeal of the retro pixel art. But personally, I found the world a little gloomy and lifeless. That‚Äôs totally a taste thing, and I respect the creative choice. It just didn‚Äôt do much for me.

I really did try to find positives. If nothing else, Stardew Valley helped pave the way for other life sims to build on the formula and evolve it. I‚Äôve definitely seen this idea pulled off in ways that resonated with me more. That said, the community around the game is lovely. I met some genuinely kind people who encouraged me to keep going when I was struggling to stay interested.

My biggest frustration? That nagging feeling like I should be enjoying it. Like I was missing something magical everyone else could see. But the truth is - sometimes even the most beloved games just don‚Äôt click. And that‚Äôs okay.

Final Thoughts:
I fully respect how much this game means to others. It clearly struck a chord with thousands of players - and that‚Äôs great. But if you‚Äôre after something more emotionally engaging, visually vibrant, or relaxing without the grind, there are plenty of other cosy games that might be a better fit.

üå± Rating: 5/10 (personally)

üåæ Stardew Valley ‚Äî The Game That Feels Like Home

I didn‚Äôt expect Stardew Valley to mean so much to me when I first started it. I thought it was just a farming sim ‚Äî something casual to relax with after work. But the more I played, the more it felt like a quiet, healing world I could escape to.

There‚Äôs something incredibly peaceful about the rhythm of this game. Planting crops, fishing by the river, hearing the soft rain, or just walking through town at sunset ‚Äî it all makes me feel calm in a way few games ever do. Every little thing feels meaningful, even the smallest progress.

What surprised me most is how real the villagers feel. They‚Äôre not just NPCs ‚Äî they have their own stories, moods, and struggles. Sometimes when life feels heavy, I‚Äôll log in and just talk to them, check on my animals, and end the day watching the stars from my farm. It‚Äôs weirdly comforting.

I think Stardew Valley is more than a game. It‚Äôs a reminder to slow down, to breathe, to find joy in simple things. It helped me feel grounded again ‚Äî like I could pause the noise of real life for a while and just‚Ä¶ exist peacefully.

This game is wholesome and slow-paced, allowing for the appreciation of the warm, heartening ambient within. The story of this game will definitely capture many people living in the modern life. It can even be better to explore with friends, given they also have not played the game yet, as it can spark a few enjoyable conversations about this game or perhaps about something else. Unfortunately, I gradually discover that this game is too peaceful for me throughout hours of playing.

Personally, to enjoy this game, it must truly be your place to relax: playing after a long day of, say, work, school or tedious routine to temporarily escape from reality and [i]feel[/i] the character that you control. Otherwise, this game can easily get mundane.

I do recommend this game to people who "already exerted their effort on something else" like full-time employees from working; I just would not recommend it to people like me who see games as a place to give myself a challenge.

One of my favorite games right now is Stardew Valley. It's the kind of game that allows you to slow down, take your time, and simply enjoy your own little world. It's such a calm and soothing experience. 

My favorite thing about the plot progression is how distinct it seems. It's more than just farming; it's about forming bonds with people, learning secrets, and seeing the town develop alongside you. Whether you're farming, fishing, mining, or assisting the locals, each day in the game feels satisfying in its own unique manner.

The amount of depth hidden in such a seemingly straightforward game is astounding. There's always something fresh to learn, and the flexibility to play at my own pace makes it even better.

üåø 170 Hours Later‚Ä¶ Still One of the Best Gaming Experiences I've Had

I‚Äôve spent 170 hours in Stardew Valley, and honestly, I could easily spend 170 more. This game is pure magic. It starts off simple‚Äîyou inherit a rundown farm and move to a quiet town‚Äîbut it quickly becomes so much more than just planting crops and feeding chickens.
The freedom to play your way is what makes it special. Some days I‚Äôm deep in the mines chasing rare loot, other days I‚Äôm fishing by the ocean just to hear the waves. I‚Äôve built up my farm from scratch, turned it into a thriving little paradise, and still find new things to tweak and improve. There‚Äôs always a new goal to chase, whether it‚Äôs completing the Community Center, unlocking new areas, or just decorating my farmhouse to perfection.

The characters in Pelican Town are surprisingly deep. You start off thinking they‚Äôre just quirky NPCs, but as you build relationships, you uncover real stories‚Äîsome funny, some emotional, some unexpectedly dark. It makes the town feel alive, and I genuinely care about these pixel people.
The seasonal changes, the music, the festivals, the little secrets hidden throughout the game‚Äîit all adds up to an experience that‚Äôs cozy, rewarding, and endlessly replayable. Even after 170 hours, I‚Äôm still discovering new details and trying out new strategies.
If you‚Äôre looking for a game that lets you relax, explore, and build something meaningful at your own pace, Stardew Valley is it. 

It‚Äôs not just a game‚Äîit‚Äôs a place I love coming back to.

What can be said about Stardew Valley that hasn't already been said? While not my most favorite farming game, Stardew offers deep farming gameplay with a lot of options and customization, and a ton of content.  Definetely worth the price, especially since it seems to still be getting free content updates.

I think it says a lot about this game that 99% of the ‚Äúnegative‚Äù reviews are things like, ‚ÄúI can‚Äôt marry Robin or Linus,‚Äù or ‚ÄúI‚Äôm failing my finals because of this game.‚Äù My personal favorite. Honestly, stop scrolling through the bad reviews and just buy the game ‚Äî it‚Äôs amazing. 10/10.

I‚Äôve been playing for about seven years now, and I still absolutely love it. Sure, I despise the Skull Cavern (who doesn‚Äôt?), but that‚Äôs what multiplayer is for ‚Äî dragging a friend along to share the pain.

I have zero complaints. Updates roll out flawlessly, and on the rare occasion something goes wrong, it‚Äôs fixed almost immediately. You can tell this game was made by someone who genuinely cares. Eric didn‚Äôt do it for money or fame ‚Äî he built something that people could truly enjoy. And it shows.

Thank you, Eric. I‚Äôve never found another game quite like this one, not even among the imitators. It might not be for everyone ‚Äî but honestly, it kind of is.

If you are going to use a wiki as a list of what to do, it's fine. Just don't look for in-game clarity as to what to do. 

If you are looking for a build a house and have a farm sim it's okay. 

Don't expect much of a challenge other than keeping the list of things to gather/find straight. The combat in the game is fairly trivial.

The order of operations isn't forced so you will find yourself doing things out of order and it makes the experience more very poor (read: annoying/frustrating) when you discover something that would have made a prior experience more enjoyable. 

The ui is "okay".  alignment issues seem to happen periodically and mouse click actions by default never seem to quite be what i expect (even after 10 hours). maybe it's too many years of diablo?

Warming : this game will ruin your social life. It's incredibly adictive, you can easily spent hours on it when you just wanted to play "one more day". The gameplay loop is a little repetitive, but it's also part of what make this game so easy to get lost into. This game is way bigger than what it look like at first, and it will take hours and hours before you unlocked every little things in it. The only (small) dark point is that the begining is a little slow, but once you start to unlock more place, farm upgrade, tools... it quickly pick up pace. And as a bonus, the modding community is awesome : whether it be to ameliorate some part of the gameplay, or to expend the game ever more, you will find tons of mods for you, multiplying by the thousand the already packed game experience.

Very nice farming game, not for everyone, but it's really fun with friends, there's pretty much always something to do, and something about having to keep track of 20 things at once in your head really tickles the tism, you can micromanage everything to hell and back, or you can just do a thing you like, there's a lot of RNG in the game, though usually you do get a lot of chances to 'roll' the drop table so it balances out, for your first year I would try to not use the WIKI but I also understand people who do.

Its been a long time since I played this game. I first bought this game when I was 14 years ago in 2017 on mobile because didn't have a computer or laptop to get this on steam. Finishing the community center and I remember some bits and pieces of this game, but this game isn't what I remember now that I'm older. 22 now. Now that I'm playing this with mature eyes, and memories are coming back... This game is way more depressing than it seems, and for that. This game is phenomenal. You basically created a catfish as a game. It looks cozy on the outside, but if you pay attention to the little details, you will realize just how fucked up and depressed everyone in this town is. And only you the farmer can fix it.

‚≠êÔ∏è‚≠êÔ∏è‚≠êÔ∏è‚≠êÔ∏è‚≠êÔ∏è ‚Äì ‚ÄúTouch Grass: The Game‚Äù

Stardew Valley isn‚Äôt just a farming sim ‚Äî it‚Äôs free therapy disguised as pixel art. One minute you‚Äôre planting parsnips, the next you‚Äôre knee-deep in an emotional connection with a fictional villager who hates mayonnaise. It‚Äôs cozy, it‚Äôs wholesome, and it somehow makes watering virtual crops feel more fulfilling than most real-world jobs.

The atmosphere is immaculate. Birds chirping, seasons changing, the satisfying ‚Äúplink‚Äù of a watering can ‚Äî it‚Äôs like a warm hug from the universe. Every day feels like a tiny story, whether you‚Äôre fishing at sunrise or accidentally gifting someone literal garbage because you misclicked (we‚Äôve all been there).

The storytelling is sneakily deep, too. Beneath the cutesy exterior is a world full of small-town drama, emotional arcs, and weirdly relatable life lessons. It‚Äôs wholesome without being cringe, emotional without trying too hard ‚Äî and that‚Äôs rare.

That said, the ‚Äúending‚Äù (if you can call it that) doesn‚Äôt exactly blow your socks off. It‚Äôs more of a soft fade-out than a mic drop, and once you‚Äôve done everything, there‚Äôs not a massive reason to replay from scratch. But that first playthrough? Pure, serotonin-fueled magic.

10/10 ‚Äì Would ignore real responsibilities to harvest virtual blueberries again.

[h2] A Cozy Farm Fiesta [/h2]
I‚Äôve been lost in Stardew Valley since 2020, and I‚Äôm finally scribbling this review because I noticed it‚Äôs missing one, and everyone‚Äôs grabbing those sparkly Steam awards :D 

This game was my ultimate happy place, a perfect blend of chill farming, cozy vibes, and small-town charm. I‚Äôve dated every villager (yep, I‚Äôm a serial heartbreaker, no regrets, cheated my way through all the heart events), popped out a gaggle of pixel kids, and built a farm so massive it‚Äôs practically a veggie empire. 
Oh, and I conquered Journey of the Prairie King without a single death ;)
I‚Äôve done every quest, maxed every skill, and adored every second of tending my adorable animals, petting my pup, and making my farm a cute masterpiece. The music‚Äôs a warm hug, the festivals are pure joy, and there‚Äôs always something new to uncover like secret caves, villager gossip, or just rearranging my flowerbeds. No stress, just pure bliss. 

[b] Pros [/b]: Romanced everyone, farm‚Äôs a stunner, Prairie King slayer, kid central, all the cozy feels.
[b] Cons [/b]: Nada
[b] Recommendation [/b]: Grab it, grow it, love it

You abandon your soulless corporate job and moved to a dilapidated farm outside a town in the idyllic countryside. Normally this would be a terrible career move, but you are confident you can become a millionaire selling potatoes and eggs and that your 401k was useless this whole time. There is an inordinate amount of eyeglasses in the river. The town drunk somehow hasn't had her CDL revoked. The girl with purple hair eats rocks. The only thing that makes the goth kid happy is frogs. The owner of the local general store is a turd. There is no school, but somehow there is funding for a museum. The ghost of your dead grandfather threatens to haunt you for years. Somehow, farm implements made from gold have more tensile strength than iron. Steel hasn't been invented yet. Every week, without a word, you hand every resident of the town a fresh jar of mayonnaise. Somehow, this makes nearly everyone in town fall in love with you. An unbreakable bond of friendship forged in the fire of eggs and vinegar with you, a mysterious condiment tycoon wearing a trash can lid on your head.

Out of all the games I play, Stardew is by far the one I return to the most. Every aspect of this game blends together to make it feel like you, yourself are actually the farmer. It is a great way to escape the reality that is life. You are free to build your place however you want. The possibilities are endless. The limit to what you can do is your imagination. Single-player or Multiplayer You will always find yourself racing to see how fast you can complete the museum, community center, and reach perfection. I've had plenty of fun times with friends or by myself. Multiplayer lets each individually play how they want. You have the one who dives into the mines the first chance they get. You have the fishermen who fish all day. You have the farmhand. You have the one who does it all! The one who befriends all the villagers. At the end of the day though you all come together and take a step back to reflect on the progress you made. This game will always remain in my list of games to play.

Stardew Valley is the most comforting and rewarding slice of life game I have played. It looks simple at first but it unfolds into a deep and surprisingly rich experience that keeps pulling me back day after day. The loop is perfect. You start each morning planning your tasks, check the weather, water your crops, feed your animals, and decide whether to head into town, explore the mines, go fishing, or work on upgrades for your farm. Every minute feels purposeful and the small choices you make add up over time in a way that is both relaxing and satisfying.

The world is packed with personality. Pelican Town feels alive, with characters that have routines, birthdays, personal stories, and heart events that make them feel like real neighbors. Building friendships is not just a checklist. Conversations change with the seasons and with your relationship progress, and gift preferences actually make sense once you learn more about each person. Festivals break up the calendar with fun activities and unique rewards, and they give the town a real sense of community.

The progression is excellent. Early on you struggle with energy and time, but small upgrades like better tools, sprinklers, kegs, and barns open up new possibilities. The Community Center bundles give you clear goals and push you to try every part of the game, from foraging and fishing to cooking and animal care. If you prefer a different route you can partner with Joja and rebuild the town a different way. By the time you reach late game you can automate huge parts of your farm, breed animals, create artisan goods, decorate to your taste, and still find reasons to explore.

There is a surprising amount of adventure. The mines and later combat areas add risk and reward, with meaningful gear upgrades, gems, and resources that feed back into crafting and farming. Fishing deserves a special mention. It can be tricky at first, but once it clicks it becomes a relaxing way to spend time, earn money, and fill out collections. The soundtrack ties it all together with gentle themes that change by season and by area, and the pixel art is gorgeous with cozy lighting, weather effects, and the best autumn vibes in any game.

Quality of life is strong. The game teaches you gently and lets you learn by doing. The day timer and energy system encourage planning without ever feeling punishing. Crafting menus, chests, and tool upgrades make routine tasks smooth, and there are lots of small touches that show real care, like being able to reorganize buildings, move sprinklers, or label storage in your own way. Performance is rock solid on both keyboard and controller, and co op is a blast, with shared goals and a nice division of labor between farming, mining, and town errands.

What I love most is the freedom. You can focus on crops and artisan goods, become a fishing expert, design the prettiest farm layout, chase every collection, speed run profits, or take it slow and just enjoy the seasons. There is always a new project within reach. One week I am remodeling the farmhouse and landscaping with paths and fences. The next I am grinding for ore to upgrade sprinklers or trying a new crop rotation. Even after hundreds of days there are secrets, new cut scenes, hidden areas, and rare items to discover.

If I had a gentle warning, it is that time management can be tight early on and the fishing mini game can feel tough until you get a few skill levels and better rods. Stick with it. Those systems start to feel great once you settle in, and the sense of progression is worth it.

Stardew Valley is cozy, generous, and endlessly replay able. It respects your time, rewards your creativity, and makes even the smallest accomplishments feel meaningful. I love this game and I cannot recommend it enough.

This review is for the people for whom hearing "it's just a game" in relation to a title they enjoy is baffling and even a bit insulting. 

Stardew Valley worth every single moment I spent in it and many moments that I haven't (yet, perhaps). Best enjoyed with a (close) friend or a partner (especially if both of you have never played it). A huge, beautiful world with a plethora of things to do, accompanied by stunning music. There's no deadlines, only dates. Everything you've missed can be done the next year, and waiting for it you'll find so many new enticing things that you'll get carried away and miss the day you needed again, and you won't be even mad about it. The amount of mods (especially large, rivaling some games' DLCs by size and quality) can make you spend multiple thousand hours in it. Whether you are a relaxed played who cherishes their square of pumpkins and waters them by hand, or a raving capitalist seeking to become the local Scrooge McDuck, or something in between (like me, who had multiple spreadsheets balancing the beauty and completeness of the farm with the profits to be had), you'll love it. Give it a go. And check out Nexus Mods. This seems to be the only game that can be called truly wholesome down there.

P.S okay scratch the thing about Nexus, that place must be purged with wrath of a thousand suns

‚ÄúWhy I Stole Caroline from Pierre‚Äù ‚Äì A Stardew Valley Love Story 

When I first arrived in Pelican Town, all I wanted was peace. I was tired of the noise of the city, the endless grind, the feeling that life was passing me by one cubicle at a time. I came here to find something simple: dirt under my nails, sun on my face, and maybe, if the stars were kind, a few friendly faces.

I didn‚Äôt expect her.

The first time I stepped into Pierre‚Äôs General Store, I was just looking for parsnip seeds. But when I saw Caroline, everything else faded. Her laughter filled the room like sunlight through dusty windows, her green hair catching the glow of the afternoon light. She smiled politely, asked how the farm was going, and I forgot how to speak for a moment. I told myself it was nothing, a harmless crush on a friendly villager.

But days turned into weeks, and soon I was visiting the store every morning. Pierre would brag about his prices while I pretended to browse, sneaking glances toward the sunroom where Caroline sipped tea and read quietly. Sometimes she would look up and smile, and the world would stop for a heartbeat.

She loved the simple things: tea, fresh flowers, the sound of the rain on the roof. I started bringing her little gifts, a daffodil from my field, a cup of green tea I brewed myself, a diamond when my mine trips were lucky. She always thanked me softly, her voice like spring wind. I told myself it was innocent. It wasn‚Äôt.

The town began to whisper. Pierre grew colder. But I couldn‚Äôt stop. When she invited me to share tea with her one morning, I knew I was lost. The scent of jasmine filled the air as she spoke about her dreams, how she once wanted to travel, to see the world beyond Pelican Town, before life settled her into routine. ‚ÄúSometimes,‚Äù she said, ‚ÄúI feel like my heart belongs to another season.‚Äù

That was the moment. The one where everything changed.

It wasn‚Äôt sudden; love rarely is. It grows slowly, like the crops we tend, roots deepening quietly beneath the surface. Every glance, every conversation, every shared silence made it harder to ignore. I wasn‚Äôt just the farmer anymore. I was the person who reminded her what it felt like to dream.

Pierre tried to fight it. He slashed prices, gave me dirty looks at festivals, and once, I swear, sold me defective fertilizer out of spite. But love doesn‚Äôt need discounts. It needs honesty, patience, and the courage to follow your heart even when it leads somewhere you shouldn‚Äôt go.

The night she came to my farmhouse, the rain was pouring. She stood at my door, soaked but smiling, eyes shining with something I had never seen before. ‚ÄúI can‚Äôt pretend anymore,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúI‚Äôve lived my whole life for others. I want to live for myself now. With you.‚Äù

That‚Äôs how it began, not with fireworks, but with quiet truth.

Now, years later, Caroline and I live together on the farm. She tends to her tea saplings in the mornings while I work the fields. In the evenings, we sit by the fire, sipping wine made from our first harvest of ancient fruit, listening to the soft hum of crickets outside. Our two children chase fireflies by the pond, their laughter echoing through the valley. Sometimes, when I see her watching them with that gentle smile, I realize that this life is everything we ever wanted.

Pierre still runs the General Store. We visit him sometimes. It‚Äôs awkward, but there‚Äôs peace between us now. Maybe he understands. Maybe he always did. After all, the heart isn‚Äôt a store. You can‚Äôt own it, you can‚Äôt stock it, you can‚Äôt sell it. You can only nurture it, and hope it blooms.

And Caroline? She‚Äôs still the same, kind, warm, and a little mischievous. Every spring, she plants new flowers around our home, and every year, the valley seems just a little brighter.

I came to Stardew Valley to escape the noise of the world. I found love instead.

Talking to a wizard who lives in a shack.

Watering crops at 6 AM like it‚Äôs a full-time job ‚Äî without the pay or benefits.

I went in thinking I‚Äôd play ‚Äúone day.‚Äù
It‚Äôs now Year 4, my grandpa‚Äôs ghost has judged me, I married a guy who keeps giving me driftwood, and I‚Äôve somehow memorized everyone‚Äôs birthday.

Stardew Valley is not a game.

This is my 3rd time buying this game. Went from Switch -> Xbox One -> and now Steam. I recommend this game to quite literally everyone. Usually when recommending games to others, there is a lot of context needed - who are you? What games do you already like? What are you in the mood to play right now? But this game man... it's truly for everyone. It was confirmed for me when my younger brother got his girlfriend, who isn't into games at all, to play co-op with him. Their experience playing together late-nights ended up becoming one of their most cherished memories of the relationship. It was (and still is) very heartwarming to see.

This game is filled with charm. Everything from the peaceful OST and environments, to the vibrant pixel-art, to the characters of the NPC's makes this game feel alive. You can truly feel the passion that went into this game that was developed by ONE man. That's the most inspiring part of it all. This game was developed solely by a single dev who wanted to make something great. He struggled with making it. That it too so much time. That friends and family were wondering what he was doing with his life. And he started to question himself at times and get depressed. But he stuck with it because he believed in what he was making. I mention all of this because if you know this while you are playing, it will add to the introspective nature of this game. To the inspiration it provides you. Yes, somehow left-clicking your mouse so that you can axe down a tree in a pixelated game will inspire you. Idk what it is. The game is just very meditative, almost like the music, the enivornment, the core gameplay forces you to zone out a little and self-reflect/day dream as you play. [b]Which leads me to my biggest advice for new players[/b];

[b]Play this game without any help from online or without any background podcasts on[/b]. Immerse yourself in it. Play with no distractions. You don't have to rush anything in this game. Min-maxing takes the fun out of it. Just explore and do things at your own pace. Enjoy the nice OST and let it sweep you away into that self-reflective state it puts you in. Forego your podcasts while you play so that your mind is not focused on something. Again, this game is very meditative. You don't want to be in a focused state of mind, but instead be gently swept into that daydream-like state the game puts you in. Because of that, I think the best way to experience the game is handheld. So on your Switch or Steam Deck. Lying down in bed playing this game is a divine experience. I'm writing this review on steam, and while I'm still having a great experience playing this game, so far the steam/PC experience has been my least favorite. I'm always too tempted to alt + tab to look something up, to put a podcast on, to break my immersion from the many distractions on PC. It takes away from my own discovery and autonomy in game. I end up just following the meta-approach to something instead of through my own trial and error. So again, I implore you to play this game at your own pace, without any distractions. The game is designed really well in that it's intuitive - you will understand fully the mechanics of something new it throws at you. And it will drip-feed you more content as you engage with the world and characters more. When you do this at your own pace, it feels rewarding as the world opens up.

Have fun playing this beautifully crafted game.

Finished the game, and I have to say, I really enjoyed playing Stardew Valley. For a game that came out almost 9 years ago, it is still incredibly popular, and so many people are still playing it. The base game itself is amazing, with its relaxing gameplay, charming world, and endless things to do. What makes it even better are the mods. Even though the game is already great, mods can add new content, improve quality of life, and make gameplay smoother. Some of my favorites are the auto fisher for fishing and the elevator mod for the Skull Cavern, which help with some of the more tedious aspects. Overall, Stardew Valley is timeless, enjoyable, and keeps players coming back again and again.

Stardew Valley completely caught me off guard‚ÄîI never expected to enjoy it as much as I do. My friends convinced me to try it, and the game quickly won me over. That said, I don‚Äôt enjoy playing it solo; it really shines when shared with others.
It‚Äôs a cozy, charming experience that invites you to slow down and relax. There‚Äôs always something to do, some new corner to explore, or a hidden detail to discover. Each system is simple on its own, but layered together they form a surprisingly complex and satisfying whole.
Even the NPCs, who seem simple at first, start to feel alive‚Äîthey have their own routines and stories to tell. It‚Äôs a game that doesn‚Äôt rush you, and that‚Äôs its strength. Highly recommended‚Äîespecially with friends.

The local carpenter offered to build a Fish Pond for some stone, algae and seaweed. I initially put one on my farm as a novelty to house a fresh Woodskip, which somehow produced 9 more of its Woodskip fellows to fill the pond and begin producing.. wood. "The Woodskip produces wood, I wonder if other fish produce other things?" I thought, planning a second Fish Pond for a quick experiment.

4 years have passed. There are over 50 Fish Ponds covering my once fertile land. The smell must be so horrible but I have long lost my sense of it, seeing only rewards from the myriad of aquatic life trapped in their perfect environments earned from their own strange desires. One fish desired diamonds in order to expand its family, another even wanted bombs. The humblest asked for but a few cave carrots. All of them grant me tribute of fish roe that I promptly age in Preserves Jars so that I can afford more Fish Ponds. Does grandfather still watch over me, bewildered by my obsession for more profitable piscine power?

>Combat

Here's a little recommendation from me on my wife's favorite game. From the time we first started dating I knew how much she loved reading, and why. She loved immersing herself in a world that she could place herself in. When we first moved in together it would be me playing a game on the couch, her reading a book, both of us immersed in different worlds. We were doing the same things over different mediums. I wanted a game to play with her and i saw Stardew Valley on Xbox Gamepass. I downloaded it and after some slight convincing she played it with me and HOLY COW! What started as a fun game we could play together when i got home from work turned into her playing stardew across 3 different devices, building new intricate farms on every single one, delving into the deepest levels of the mines and skull caverns, sailing to ginger island and speedrunning through the walnuts. She explored nearly every avenue before purchasing it on our PC because she saw a tiktok on one little mod called Stardew Expanded. the rest is history (I'm still the designated fisherman because she's bad)

Stardew Valley: A Review by a Totally Normal Farmer Who Definitely Hasn‚Äôt Named All His Chickens After Historical Figures

Let me start by saying this: I booted up Stardew Valley to relax. A cozy farming simulator, they said. Plant some parsnips, raise a cow, marry the nice goth man. Next thing I know, it‚Äôs 2am in real life, I‚Äôm covered in virtual slime juice, and I just divorced my pixel wife because she insulted my crystal layout. And I‚Äôd do it again.

This isn‚Äôt a game. It‚Äôs a lifestyle. It‚Äôs a spiral. It‚Äôs emotional blackmail wrapped in pixel art and fiddle music.

You Wake Up With a Hoe and Depression

Your grandpa, who suspiciously dies off-screen, bequeaths you a chunk of land so overgrown it looks like a bomb went off in a forestry exhibit. You arrive in Pelican Town with nothing but a few tools, a dream, and the na√Øve hope that you‚Äôre about to live a quiet life.

You are not.

You are about to enter a wholesome-yet-chaotic capitalist nightmare where time is a lie, your neighbors have unresolved trauma, and the local wizard is peeping on you through the bushes.

Farming? Oh You Sweet, Simple Fool

On day one, you plant some parsnips. On day two, you realize you forgot to water them. On day three, a crow eats your only remaining hope. You panic, run to Pierre‚Äôs shop, and drop your last 60g on turnip seeds like a Wall Street trader who just learned about crypto.

A week later, you have four different crops, a mild gambling addiction thanks to the egg festival, and a schedule that revolves around when Pam goes to the bar.

Farming becomes a religion. The greenhouse is your temple. The sprinkler is your god.

The Mines: Where Happiness Goes to Die

Oh, you thought this was just a farming sim? Cute. Here‚Äôs a pickaxe. Go fight the horrors beneath the mountain.

The mines are where Stardew Valley stops pretending to be cozy and starts playing the boss music from your anxiety. Bats shriek at you. Slimes drop from the ceiling. You‚Äôre one swing away from passing out and waking up with a bill from the local doctor and a heartfelt letter about how they "found you in a puddle."

Somewhere around level 70, the walls start looking like they‚Äôre made of meat, and you begin to wonder if the loot is really worth it. It is. It always is.

Romance: It‚Äôs Complicated‚Ñ¢

You can date everyone. Literally everyone. The doctor? Yup. The bartender? Sure. That weird guy who eats rocks and lives in a tent? Romantic options abound.

The courtship system is charming in the way that giving someone 57 daffodils in a row until they love you is charming. "Here, have this mayonnaise. Marry me." That‚Äôs romance in Pelican Town.

But once you‚Äôre married? Oh, that‚Äôs when the emotional game begins. Your spouse might cook for you, or they might rearrange your entire home while you're out fishing. Sometimes they water your plants. Sometimes they just stare into the fireplace like they know what you did in the Skull Caverns.

You can even have kids! Or don‚Äôt. The game doesn‚Äôt care. They‚Äôll just stay toddlers forever, trapped in an endless loop of building blocks and existential dread.

JojaMart: Satan, but With Membership Perks

If you‚Äôre a good little farmer, you‚Äôll restore the community center with love, hard work, and ancient fruit wine. Or‚Ä¶ you can sign your soul over to JojaCorp for 5,000 gold and a soul-numbing corporate lifestyle that makes you feel like the villain in a Hallmark movie.

And guess what? The sprinklers are cheaper.

Capitalism wins again.

Fishing: The Real Dark Souls of Stardew Valley

I have conquered dragons in Skyrim. I‚Äôve beaten Bloodborne. But nothing prepared me for Stardew‚Äôs fishing minigame, where you must wrestle aquatic nightmares with the reflexes of a caffeinated hummingbird.

Fish will taunt you. Leap. Dive. Fake you out like they‚Äôre being controlled by a bored esports pro.

You‚Äôll finally catch a legendary fish after 40 attempts, and then forget to empty your inventory and watch it disappear while your character stares blankly into the lake like a traumatized war vet.

Decorating: Martha Stewart Meets Hoarder Simulator

You will spend five hours trying to place your scarecrow ‚Äújust right‚Äù while ignoring the fact that your house is full of unprocessed pine resin and your barn is on fire.

There are rugs. There are plants. There are entire cottagecore blogs dedicated to optimal chicken coop feng shui.
At some point, you‚Äôll stop chasing profit and start chasing aesthetics. You‚Äôll weep when your bee houses aren‚Äôt perfectly aligned. You‚Äôll spiral because your kitchen table clashes with your wallpaper.

You will become the monster.

Music, Art, and Emotional Damage

The music? Hauntingly peaceful. Until it triggers a memory of when you passed out at 1:59 AM because you were too far from home and the spirits were ‚Äúvery displeased.‚Äù

The art? Pixel-perfect joy, bursting with personality. Every season brings color shifts that make you feel like you‚Äôre living inside a Studio Ghibli film... that occasionally asks you to murder shadow beasts for coal.

Final Thoughts: I Wasn‚Äôt Prepared

Stardew Valley is not a game.
It‚Äôs a perfect storm of comfort, chaos, and compulsive time management.
It‚Äôs a soft blanket‚Ä¶ with a knife hidden in the folds.
It‚Äôs where you go to escape capitalism, and end up selling jam at a 900% markup like a fruit-flavored war criminal.

You will laugh.
You will cry.
You will try to make friends and end up giving someone a rock and getting hated forever.
You will forget who you are outside of this farm.
You will click "sleep" and mean it with your whole heart.

Final Verdict: 10/10

Would build an entire wine empire just to impress a woman who only likes amethysts and brooding.
Would do it all again tomorrow.
There is always something to do in this game. It's laid back and fun to play.

Bought a farm. Grew some parsnips. Accidentally married the local emo. 10/10.

Seriously though ‚Äî Stardew Valley is pure chill. The music? Relaxing. The art? Adorable. The villagers? Weird in the best way.

It‚Äôs the kind of game where you say ‚Äújust one more day‚Äù and suddenly it‚Äôs 3 AM and you‚Äôre emotionally invested in a chicken named Nugget. üêîüíõ

Verdict:

Genuinely one of my favorite games ever! The mechanics of friendships, fighting, and farming tie into each other very well! I started playing this game when I was barely sentient in this world, and now as I am older, I have realized that some concepts in this game are very relatable to not just me, but other people as well! I only hope for a few things: our children to grow up, date nights with spouses, potentially getting older as the years progress (?), and maybe anniversaries or a features to replay some heart cut scenes. All in all, it's a game that is not very rushing and is very patient. With almost 2,000 hours in Stardew Valley, my first ever spouse being Alex, I have still not reached perfection yet, but that's okay! Even if it takes me another six years, I will complete my save file with my pookie Alex!!!! (Also Sebastian has grown on me a lot too X3) I even have the cookbook, and even though I don't really like Demetrius, the Green Bean Hotpot is SO GOOD XD.

I‚Äôm not a big fan of pixel art games, but Stardew Valley completely changed my mind. It‚Äôs one of those games that you start just to ‚Äúsee what it‚Äôs about,‚Äù and then somehow you‚Äôve been farming for five in-game years and know every villager‚Äôs birthday by heart. It‚Äôs honestly the definition of relaxing, the kind of game where doing absolutely nothing still feels productive.

The chill atmosphere is what makes it shine. You can farm, fish, mine, decorate your house, or just vibe with the townspeople. Getting to know each villager is surprisingly fun. They all have their own stories, quirks, and moments that make Pelican Town feel alive. There‚Äôs something really cozy about logging in just to give gifts or check what everyone‚Äôs up to.

That said, going for the achievements can be painful. Some of them feel like they were designed to test your patience, specially the fishing and crafting ones. It doesn‚Äôt ruin the game, but it does make the ‚Äúrelaxing farm life‚Äù turn into ‚Äúspreadsheet simulator‚Äù real quick if you‚Äôre chasing 100%.

Still, Stardew Valley is easily one of the best indie experiences out there. It‚Äôs peaceful, addictive, and way more emotional than it has any right to be. Even if you‚Äôre not into pixel art games, it‚Äôs worth giving a shot, you might end up loving it as much as I did!

It is really hard to describe exactly how I feel about this game. It should be obvious from the sea of stellar reviews, but this is one of the best games I have played in recent memory. It is calming, fun, and is so jam filled with content it makes my head spin, in a good way. There is such a lively community for this game that have been so kind to me and so many others. If nothing else Concerned Ape created a game that has brought countless people together in solidarity at the wonders of farming, combat, romance, and so many others. I have independently bought this game on three different console, and if that does not say something I am not sure what will! This game has gotten me through hard times, good times, and has consistently gotten better with every time I play it. Concerned Ape has poured his soul into this game multiple times over, and has not stopped the ball rolling. Needless to say I am very excited for not only the future of Stardew Valley, but Haunted Chocolatier and anything that comes afterwards.

When I first played Stardew a few years ago, I found the broad scope of it to be a bit intimidating. There's so much to do, so much to explore and see. I hadn't even fixed the bus up at that point, and I still haven't unlocked all the areas in my current playthrough yet. But combined with figuring out what my priorities are as I go, using wikis and guides along the way, and remembering that I don't need to take myself too seriously, this game has become a comfort for me. I find that I can play it both absent-mindedly, tending to the farm in a sort of routine, or be more engaged by trying to unlock everything and conquer quests. It does a good job of being repetitive enough to be familiar, but varied enough to keep it engaging. I look forward to seeing how things go from here - I haven't even finished my second year yet with my new playthrough so I know there's still lots to uncover and explore!

For years, I saw Stardew Valley on every storefront and "must-play" list. And for years, I scoffed. A farming simulator? A "cozy" game? I live for the punishing, precise combat of Dark Souls, the brutal mastery of Sekiro, the unforgiving worlds where a single mistake means death. I thought a game about planting parsnips and talking to villagers would be a waste of my precious gaming time. A shallow, casual experience that couldn't possibly offer a challenge or, more importantly, respect my time.

I have never been more wrong about a game.

Out of sheer desperation for something different, I finally downloaded it. The first day was confusing. I was just‚Ä¶ watering plants. Cleaning up my farm. It felt slow. But then, something clicked. I realized the challenge in Stardew Valley isn't about reaction times or pattern memorization. It's about optimization, strategy, and long-term planning.

The Skull Cavern isn't the Catacomb, but descending its floors with bombs, staircases, and a well-timed sword swing against a thos anoying flying skulls head!.. it requires a level of preparation and resource management that any Souls veteran would appreciate. Trying to maximize your farm's gold-per-day output is a complex puzzle. Managing your energy, time, and resources each day is a constant, engaging challenge. This game isn't "casual"; it's just that the difficulty is cerebral, not reflexive.

But the true masterstroke, and what made me feel the most foolish for dismissing it, is how profoundly Stardew Valley respects my time.

In Stardew, every single day, no matter how you spend it, is progress. Did you spend the whole day fishing? You leveled up your skill and earned gold. Did you just wander around talking to people? You‚Äôre closer to unlocking a new cutscene or a community event. Did you pass out at 2 AM because you lost track of time in the mines? You lost a little money and maybe an item, but you kept all your ore and your combat experience. The game doesn't punish you for failure; it gently nudges you to do better next time. It‚Äôs a game that understands that your free time is valuable and ensures that time is never truly wasted.

I now see the "coziness" not as a lack of depth, but as a brilliant design philosophy. It‚Äôs a world that wants you to succeed, to build, and to belong. It provides a sense of accomplishment.

I wish I hadn't let my own gaming snobbery keep me from this masterpiece for so long. I was the one being casual in my judgment, not the game in its design.

So, to anyone viewing this, especially my fellow masochists who live in Lands Between and Lordran: give this farm a chance. You might be surprised by the deep, strategic, and incredibly rewarding experience that lies beneath its peaceful surface.

And to ConcernedApe, the developer: Thank you. Thank you for creating a world that is both challenging and kind, and for showing this hardened skeptic that a game doesn't need to break you to build you up. An absolute masterpiece.

Preheat & Prep
Preheat your oven to 160¬∞C (320¬∞F).
Line an 8x8 inch (20x20 cm) pan with parchment paper, leaving some overhang to lift the brownies out later.
(Using parchment prevents crisp edges!)

Melt Chocolate & Butter
In a heatproof bowl set over simmering water (bain-marie), melt the chocolate and butter together.
Stir gently until smooth, then remove from heat and let cool slightly (about 5 minutes).

Mix the Sugars & Eggs
In a large bowl, whisk together granulated sugar, brown sugar, eggs, and vanilla for about 2‚Äì3 minutes until slightly thickened and glossy.
You don‚Äôt need to overmix ‚Äî just until the sugar dissolves and the mixture looks creamy.

Combine Chocolate & Egg Mixture
Slowly pour the melted chocolate mixture into the eggs while whisking gently. Mix until smooth and uniform.

Add Dry Ingredients
Sift in flour, cocoa powder, and salt.
Fold gently with a spatula ‚Äî stop as soon as no dry streaks remain.
(Overmixing creates air, which can make crisp edges ‚Äî so keep it gentle!)

Bake
Pour the batter into your lined pan.
Tap the pan lightly on the counter to remove air bubbles.
Bake for 22‚Äì25 minutes, or until the top is just set and a toothpick comes out with a few moist crumbs (not wet batter).

Cool Slowly
Let the brownies cool completely in the pan at room temperature ‚Äî at least 1 hour.
(Cooling too fast or cutting early can make the edges firm up.)

Stardew Valley is a heartwarming and wonderfully addictive farming simulator that offers players a peaceful escape into rural life. From planting crops and raising animals to fishing, mining, and building friendships, the game provides endless opportunities for creativity and relaxation. The pixel art style is charming and nostalgic, and the calming soundtrack perfectly complements the game‚Äôs cozy atmosphere. One of the game‚Äôs biggest strengths is its open-ended design‚Äîthere‚Äôs no pressure to rush, allowing players to progress at their own pace and enjoy the journey. Each season brings new activities, events, and surprises, keeping the gameplay fresh and engaging. The townspeople are full of personality, and forming relationships with them adds emotional depth to the experience. Whether you're playing solo or with friends in co-op mode, Stardew Valley delivers a wholesome, rewarding experience that‚Äôs easy to pick up and hard to put down. It's a true indie gem that continues to shine.

I picked this game up originally back in, like, 2018 or 19 or whatever, and thought it was pretty awesome save for the terrible combat.

Fast forward to now, and it's gotten even better, with so many quality of life improvements and extra content that you'd be insane not to capitalize on the sheer bang for your buck. Except for the combat.

Some games will give you the power fantasy of carving through demons, some will have you leading armies and out-smarting your enemies. This game gives you the ultimate power fantasy for a man in 2025: living off the land with a beautiful wife and kids. And the only demons you're fighting off are A) the evil Amazon stand-in and B) the stupid effing flying enemies that drag the game to a halt as you stand there knocking them away and waiting for them to bounce back like the slowest, most boring game of paddle ball in the universe. Combat sucks.

There'll inevitably be that time where you realize that you're 90% done with the game, even if that 10% will take a hefty while to achieve, and that'll drag down your mood. But it'll take you _quite_ a while to get there, and it's all worth it for that sense of accomplishment. And if the problem is, "Aw, I was hoping there'd be just a *little* bit more," then I'd say, after forty-something hours, that's a freakin' accomplishment.

If I had only _one_ piece of feedback...we could *maybe* have enemies die in less than twenty hits. Maybe. Definitely. Absolutely. Enemies shouldn't take nearly twenty hits to kill with the highest-level sword in the game. We ain't here for the paddle ball, Eric - we're here for the *literally everything else*. The likable npcs, the cute gals, the mysteries, and the soil. And fishing, sometimes. When I'm in the mood. I'm not often in the mood. But we're getting off track.

Ah, Stardew Valley. An absolute classic. You can probably infer from my hours played that I really like this game. Stardew has it all: cozy farming simulator, incredibly rich world building and npcs who will have you obsessed if you pay attention to what they say, lots of room for personal design and creativity, a plethora of choices to make, and genuinely challenging gameplay in many areas. 

I will caution new players to not overdo their play time. Although stardew is a wonderful game, it is a little too good at getting you hooked. Try to limit your play sessions to 2-3 hours max, if not less. Otherwise, it is VERY easy to burn out early. And that sucks for everyone, because you will definitely not make it long enough to experience all the game has to offer if you don't pace yourself. 

My other criticism is mostly around the late game experience. Opportunities like Ginger Island and the Skull Cave mean you do have things to do around year 3/4, but it's quite difficult to really dive into those, because at that point in the game you have a very active farm that needs daily tending to. So you're constantly jumping back and forth and not doing either the best you could. 

I finished the skull cave but mostly ignored Ginger Island at this point in the game, and instead opted for mods, which has been a great decision for me. There is a very thriving modding community on this game and you should totally check it out even as a first time player. There are simple mods out there that won't interfere with your "genuine" experience, but will just get rid of some minor annoyances that don't do the game any good. 

If I could add anything to this game it would be making spouses and children more helpful. I am begging concerned ape to let us assign chores to our spouse and kids, once they're grown. I would also love if the children were a little bit more anything. They barely qualify as npcs right now in my book. 

I still recommend this game, which is very close to my heart!!
